Issue.Title: Content.Load<Song>() tries to load OGG on Windows project
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # # # GitHub issues are only for bug reports / feature requests # if you have a question, ask it on the community site: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below -->
Hello Monogame community. First of all, I don't know exacly if it is a bug or not. For me it looks more like the way VS compiler handles and builds the assemblies or maybe I have done something wrong. For this, I have decided to write this issue to warn the others about this problem and even learn something new.
I've reproduced it on the current build (3.8.0.1641) and haven't tested the same thing on previous ones.
My solution is designed like this:
Project 1 - Game Project <- All contents are here. Content.Load<Song>() is also called in this project. Project 2 - Library Project
Where game contains a reference for the library project and both contains a reference for Monogame assemblies. Initially I was testing my game's performance on DesktopGL and then I have decided to compare it on WindowsDX. I have updated the Game Project reference to WindowsDX, but I forgot to update the Library's reference to WindowsDX. And that was my mistake. For my surprise the Game Project's Content.Load<Song> was using it's DesktopGL version and was attempting to open songs as OGG instead WindowsDX's WMA.
I believe the exception is well know here: System.IO.InvalidDataException: 'Could not determine container type!'.

Issue.Title: Target netcoreapp3.1 in addition to netstandard2.0
Issue.Description: This will allow for the conditional use of new .NET Core APIs that are not included in .NET Standard. The most interesting are probably `System.Buffers.ArrayPool` (superseding `MonoGame.Framework.Utilities.ByteBufferPool`) and many new method overloads in the BCL with `Span` parameters, which might be handy for reducing allocations in some hot paths (I'm guessing as I don't know the internals of MonoGame).

Issue.Title: Documentation inconsistancy.
Issue.Description:
Applys to all platforms all systems.
The issue is a point of confusion for new people and for reference potentially leading to a failed registration of the pipeline tool.
Under getting started.
found here.
At the bottom of the page marked Optional which (should be marked Recommended). Seen before the more detailed instructions with cavets for installing and registering the pipeline tool later on.
> > To register the MGCB Editor tool with Windows and Visual Studio 2019, run the following from the Command-Prompt. > > dotnet tool install --global dotnet-mgcb-editor > mgcb-editor --register
Doesn't match the more detailed instructions.
Found at the bottom here.
> The MGCB Editor is published as a .NET Core tool, Make sure you have the .NET Core SDK installed if you wish to install the editor. You can download it here. > > In a command prompt/terminal window, run the following command to install the MGCB Editor: > > dotnet tool install -g dotnet-mgcb-editor > > For development branches, you will need to ensure you have the dev channel NuGet registered and include the version number in the command, for example: > > dotnet nuget add source -n MonoGame > > dotnet tool install --global dotnet-mgcb-editor --version 3.8.0.1476-develop > > After installing mgcb-editor run the following to register the MGCB Editor as the default app for mgcb files. > > mgcb-editor --register
People using the new version and 2019 are going to use the first set of instructions which can fail. They may not read further to the segment titled tools editor when it doesn't work for the next step after getting started in sequence.
1) Their should **only** be one area for installation instructions for any specific thing listing all possible configurations and cavets. 2) Other places where there is a required awareness of these instructions should linked to that location. 3) If the majority of use cases apply to a specific topic or a link. Then that item should **not** be marked _optional_ but instead either Suggested, Recommended, Standard, or Requisite reading.
Something that implys that you should now click to here to ensure you have set everything up for your platform.

Issue.Title: [DesktopGL] Issuing duplicate source ids for sound effects, dynamic sound effects, and songs
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> Because [availableSourcesCollection is a List(int) within OpenALSoundController.cs]( multiple integers of the same value can be added to it.
There are possible instances where ReleaseSource(int sourceId) function can be is called for the same sourceId.
If two sound effect instances end up with the same source id there are invalid operation exceptions within openal leading to sounds not playing, dynamic sound effects looping, and other problems.
There are a few instances where this has occurred in our projects.
**Instance A:**
- When DynamicSoundEffects are disposed [PlatformDispose() and base.Dispose()]( are called.
- [PlatformDispose() releases the source by calling RecycleSource instead of FreeSource so HasSourceId is never set to false](
- base.Dispose() calls [base.PlatformDispose()]( which calls [FreeSource()]( and [releases the source again](
**Solution A:** This should be as easy as using controller.FreeSource() instead of [controller.RecycleSource()]( and adding a conditional check for HasSourceId == true beforehand so it cannot be disposed more than once.
--------------------------------
**Instance B:** Unfortunately that is not the only case where this can happen. There is also the possibility that GC tries to dispose SoundEffects while SoundEffectInstancePool.Update() is stopping finished sounds. Both of those instances running at the same time result in the available openAl sources list being filled with duplicate ids.
**Solution for B:** Wrap the FreeSource() functions within mutex locks so that we can be sure that the source hasn't been freed and the source isn't currently being freed before finally recycling the source.
--------------------------------

Issue.Title: Content Pipeline support for arbitrary text config files (including JSON, YAML, etc.)
Issue.Code:
csharp string json = content.Load<string>("path/to/some/config.json") JObject config = Newtonsoft.Json.Linq.JObject.Parse(json);
This would be implemented as a straightforward `ContentImporter` that reads the input file and returns a `string` result, defaulting to the `PassThroughProcessor`, since it's expected that the user will do their own processing within their game logic.
# Alternatives
One obvious alternative would be to simply read the file directly, with `System.IO.File.ReadAllText()` or a similar API. My assumption is that a lot of people would rather keep all their content files & content-loading code in one place within the MonoGame framework. Providing them an easy way to load arbitrary config files would lead to simpler & more-orthogonal business logic.
Another alternative would be for each developer to implement their own custom content importer, for example [as described in this blog post](http://blog.dylanwilson.net/posts/2015/creating-custom-content-importers-for-the-monogame-pipeline/). Unfortunately, that's a bit of an laborious process if all you want to do is load a couple simple text files and parse them from within your game.
MonoGame.Extended includes [JSON support](https://github.com/craftworkgames/MonoGame.Extended/tree/develop/Source/MonoGame.Extended.Content.Pipeline/Json), but including all of MonoGame.Extended feels like a lot just to load some JSON files -- and it only supports JSON specifically, not any other text-file formats that someone might want to use. It's also described in the code as "very nearly fully working", which does not instill confidence.
Finally, there's the approach I've actually taken in my game for now: include a JSON string inside an XML file and use XmlImporter, like so: xml <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <XnaContent> <Asset Type="System.String"> <![CDATA[ JSON goes here ]]> </Asset> </XnaContent> `
Issue.Description:
This is a feature request / design review for functionality that I'm happy to implement & contribute as long as the MonoGame devs approve of the concept. Comments / suggestions welcome!
# Proposal
Right now, the MonoGame content pipeline has the ability to import XML files via `XmlImporter`, but many folks would rather keep metadata & config files in a different format, such as JSON, Windows INI / .cfg files, YAML, etc.
Rather than implementing separate processors for every possible plain-text file format, I propose adding a generic `TextImporter` to the content pipeline, which simply reads the associated file and presents it to the user as a C# string. The user can then parse it with their favorite JSON / YAML (etc) parser; for example:
`` This *works*, but I'm not proud of it. It feels slightly cursed.
# Questions
* How do we handle the encoding of the input text files? My preference would be to only support UTF-8 files, or perhaps to make two separate importers `Utf8Importer` and `Utf16Importer` for the two most-common Unicode formats.
# Expected limitations
* We will not handle legacy non-Unicode file encodings such as Windows code pages, Shift-JIS, and so on.
* The text file will be loaded into a single string in memory. A user who wants to load a file that's too big to fit in memory should probably implement their own streaming loading system instead of trying to use the proposed `TextImporter`.

Issue.Title: Immediate crash on startup on iPad 3 running iOS 9
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below -->
MonoGame crashes during initialization on an iPad 3 physical device running iOS 9.
The current MonoGame initialization code incorrectly assumes that GLES 3 is available on a device if the iOS version number is 7 or higher.
In fact, some devices such as the iPad 3 do not support GLES 3, but they do support iOS versions up to 9.
The proposed fix is to first attempt to initialize GLES 3, and if that fails, fall back to GLES 2, per the [Apple developer documentation]( (see Listing 2-1).

Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> The [documentation for SDL_GameControllerMapping]( explicitly states that the returned string must be freed with SDL_free(). [MonoGame's implementation]( gets gamepad mappings and converts the native strings to .NET strings, but the associated `IntPtr` is never freed. This happens every time [PlatformGetCapabilities is called]( on a connected gamepad.
A simple fix would be to pass the IntPtr into SDL_free in GetMapping right after obtaining the .NET string but before returning it.

Issue.Title: macOS not looking in "Frameworks" for .dylibs in .app bundles
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> When loading libraries such as SDL on macOS, MonoGame looks in the directory of the Microsoft.Xna.Framework assembly. This means the .dylib files must be in the same folder as the .DLL files (or executable if using mkbundle) for MonoGame to load them, but this shouldn't be relied on for .app bundles.
According to the [official documentation]( the SDL and OpenAL dylibs would be better suited in the "Frameworks" folder of an app bundle so the game uses the packaged version of the dylibs instead of a shared version that may be installed. Loading the libraries in the same folder as the assembly may work now, but there's no telling if this will change in future versions of macOS .app bundles, not to mention certification for the App Store.
The [OpenAL]( and [SDL]( library loaders can be changed to look for the files in "../Frameworks/" first if the platform is OSX then default to the current directory if not found, or vice versa. Basically, something similar to what [TitleContainer already does](

Issue.Description:
We have had some issues reported to us recently regarding our clients game on the Amazon App Store. It seems this issue has started occurring fairly recently and they all report they are on a Kindle Fire HD 10 tablet (Gen 8+, doesn't occur on our Fire HD 10 Gen 7).
We only have fairly vague bug reports from customers, but largely they seem to say it wont launch at all. And one or two report it either won't install, or will crash part way through loading.
It's a paid app so people are raging pretty hard and requesting refunds. We have a couple of these tablets on their way so hopefully we can reproduce on a device when it arrives.
In the meantime Amazon have supplied a log of the crash. Trawling through it I don't see a much apart from OpenAL failing to initialise. Relevant part of logs below:
``
Does this seem something likely to cause the app to fail launching? After OpenAL fails to initialise the next part of the logs shows some audio getting loaded. I'd have to double check but from what I remember audio is the first thing we load.
Any help would be much appreciated, got a pretty unhappy client on our hands :)

Issue.Title: Opening up BRUTE
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> This is not about MG itself but a core component that allows MG to run on consoles - [BRUTE]( Aside from the console-specific bits, is there a reason it's not widely available and open? There's a lack of quality open-source IL to C++ transpilers, and I'd imagine this would create a lot of new opportunities regarding .NET game development, including on desktop, mobile, and especially web platforms.
Currently available .NET AOT options (feel free to enlighten me): - **.NET Native** - specific to Windows/UWP. - **CoreRT** - in a preview state and may or may not ever fully develop, as good as it currently is. - **Unity IL2CPP** - locked down and deeply tied to their proprietary engine.
Based on BRUTE's website, BRUTE sounds like an ideal tool to have an open community of collaborators and users. We know how well it works on consoles due to all the MG games developed for them. I'd love to have a discussion about this and learn more since I don't have access to the tool.

Issue.Title: GraphicsDevice.OpenGL: MaxTextureSlots is incorrectly determined
Issue.Description:
in GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.cs PlatformSetup()
MaxTextureSlots is determined using
GL.GetInteger(GetPName.MaxTextureImageUnits, out MaxTextureSlots);
and later used by TextureCollection
in TextureCollection.OpenGL.cs PlatformSetTextures
the range used with GL.ActiveTexture(TextureUnit.Texture0 + i) is bound by MaxTextureSlots value.
However the documentation of GL.ActiveTexture() says the limit is GL_MAX_COMBINED_TEXTURE_IMAGE_UNITS -1
which in my test setup (Ubuntu 18.04 in virtualbox) is reporting 8 instead of 32 for MaxTextureImageUnits which is causing glerror 1282

Issue.Title: XACT Cue Doppler effect is not implemented
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
I was going to use the Doppler effect of moving sounds in my game using cues, after spending half a day, checked the code. Its just not implemented (!) `` So what is going on here
1. We have a distance between listener and emitter now in relative units, say meters. 2. We calculate distance between them in next second, after velocity was applied. 3. So we get relative velocity in meters per second by (1st - 2nd distance). 4. This relative velocity is actually used as V in the Doppler equation ![Doppler equation](
, where C is the speed of sound in environment, W0 is original frequency and W is final frequency. I was implemented it by Russian Wiki ( seems there is the same formula in English Wiki, but looking different. 5. This multiplier of W0 and the DopplerPitchScalar variable for XACT are the same ![XACT RPC]( just found it empirically, and it worked, but can't be fully sure. Can you guys implement it correctly ? Issue.Title: Pipeline dotnet tool
Issue.Description:
I don't believe there's been much discussion of the design of the Pipeline dotnet global tool. I'm interested in helping with that next, as I think that's the last piece that need to be nugetized.
### Open Questions
1. **Future of Pipeline tool.** **[EDIT] Resolved:** Pipeline is here to stay, while cra0zy is working on his own alternative.
> @Jjagg I am in process of writing something custom for the content builder, among the other stuff, so I'm leaving this to you. I really don't wanna touch MGCB/Pipeline Tool anymore.
_Originally posted by @cra0zy in
Should we be expecting something to replace the current tooling, or is that just personal preference or maybe an alternative option? (I assume the latter)
2. **Name.** **[EDIT] Resolved:** MGCB Editor is currently the top contender, with commands like `dotnet tool run mgcb-editor`
As a public package, "Pipeline" is too generic. What name should be used for the package and the command? (Note: our other tools are `dotnet-mgcb` and `dotnet-2mgfx`.) For example: - Tool: `dotnet-mgpipeline` - Global command: `mgpipeline` - Local command: `dotnet tool run mgpipeline`
3. **Structure.** **[EDIT] Resolved:** The platform packages can't be unified, because we want native UI controls on Windows. We can, however, package them together and have a cross-platform launcher so the experience is seamless across all platforms.
Should we package platform-specific Pipeline tools, or unify them? Is UI the only thing preventing these from being unified? Presumably shaders can just continue to not compile on non-Windows for now. - Platform-specific would be easiest since it would keep the same structure and Eto dependencies. We can publish `dotnet-mgpipeline-windows`, `dotnet-mgpipeline-mac`, `dotnet-mgpipeline-linux`, but this is clearly not ideal. - We can switch to a new cross-platform .NET Core UI framework and publish a single cross-platform tool. The most popular appears to be [Avalonia]( - We can use MonoGame.DesktopGL itself for the UI -- either a 3rd party UI framework, or maintain an _extremely_ slim set of controls just for the tools (not a part of the MG framework).
4. **MGCB dependency.** **[EDIT] Resolved:** MGCB will be packaged directly into MGCB Editor. The duplicated files aren't too large and shouldn't be much concern for devs.
How should the MGCB dependency be handled? - Just package MGCB binaries into the Pipeline tool as well? Then users who use the Pipeline tool and build with the MonoGame.Content.Builder package (#6905) would have a handful of files duplicated, but it's not a big issue. Is there a concern about the two versions needing to be manually kept in sync? - Package MGCB binaries into the Pipeline tool, but don't additionally required the MGCB tool when using the Pipeline tool. Instead use MGCB out of the Pipeline tool. See the _Usage_ option below for more details. - Have the Pipeline tool depend on the MGCB dotnet tool. This would be difficult, because if the Pipeline tool is installed globally, then it would have to also install the MGCB tool globally, which is an option we decided to avoid with MonoGame.Content.Builder. This could also be difficult to run locally out of the MonoGame repo, because the Pipeline tool would need to be able to either depend on the MGCB dotnet tool or use the local MGCB project.
5. **Usage.** **[EDIT] Resolved:** /register and /unregister CLI commands will be available to associate the app with the .mgcb extension by running `pipeline /register` (global) or `dotnet tool run pipeline /register` (local).
I expect a common scenario to be installing as a global tool, but can we enable more options? - As an additional option, I was thinking about being able to specify an option in the MonoGame.Content.Builder package (#6905) to restore the Pipeline tool instead of MGCB. This would make it easier for content designers to just clone a repo and automatically get the recommended tooling. And obviously this wouldn't have to compromise any of the core MonoGame.Content.Builder functionality. - Will we need to give up associating the `.mgcb` file extension with the tool? This doesn't seem like a good option anymore since dotnet tools can be installed globally or locally. Following the potential usage option above, in my own repos I plan to change my Pipeline extensions project into a netcoreapp that can simply call `dotnet tool run pipeline` on the correct `.mgcb` file.

Issue.Title: Use dotnet tools during build
Issue.Description:
This is a question about the design and usage of the recent dotnet tools: 2MGFX and MGCB. I haven't found much discussion of this, but please point me in the right direction if I missed a thread. Apologies for the verbosity.
#### Question
Do we expect users to manually install dotnet tools before being able to build their game, or should they get the functionality automatically from the template or a PackageReference?
I'm under the impression that MonoGame is moving toward a model where a dev can clone a game repo and build without requiring any manual installation.
#### Problem
Dotnet tools seem to be intended more as manual helpers, rather than for use in automated build steps, for the following reasons:
1. Dotnet tools are not automatically restored on build. `dotnet restore` is run on build, but still not `dotnet tool restore`. This means tools need to be manually and explicitly installed or restored. 2. Dotnet tools cannot be transitive dependencies, by design, as opposed to package references. You won't be able to reference a MonoGame.Content.Builder package that in turn references the MGCB tool. This means that any project intending to use MGCB will either need the tool installed globally, or listed in a manifest for local tool restore.
#### Solutions
Given those constraints, I see the following options:
1. Publish a MonoGame.Content.Builder package that expects the MGCB tool to be present. - The user can then choose to install the tool globally, or check in a local tool manifest and manually restore from it. - **Concern:** The user must manually install or restore the tool. 2. Publish a MonoGame.Content.Builder package that depends on the MGCB tool, but automatically runs `dotnet tool restore`. - The user can still choose to install the tool globally or check in a local tool manifest. In the case of a local manifest, though, it will be automatically restored as part of build. I'm not sure if this has perf implications or why it's not already automatic. - **Concern:** The repo must contain a local manifest, or the user must manually install the tool. 3. Keep MonoGame.Content.Builder as is. - The package has full control over the MGCB dependency, requiring no manual action. - **Concern:** This is somewhat non-standard and doesn't use the dotnet tools at all.

Issue.Title: [Todo list] Future-proofing MonoGame
Issue.Description:
Hey there!
Many efforts have been started to future-proof MonoGame and make it a modern .Net framework but it seems that there is no comprehensive centralized point where to understand how things should move forward and their current state.
Hence, I'm trying to maintain this issue to keep track of the different tasks. Please feel free to point me to any untracked tasks or progress.
I guess that we will agree on the following main objective: **making MonoGame fully .Net Standard 2.0 compliant in its entirety** (all targets, all of its tools, and its build/test/package process), while maintaining a backward compatibility where it's relevant.
This would mean: being able to consume MonoGame as a `` once protobuild is gone)
**Bonus stage for console targets (which unfortunately can't be discussed publicly):** - [x] ~Keeping VS2015 and net45 non-SDK style projects while being compatible with the parent repository structure~ (deprecated) - [x] Refactoring MGCB and Pipeline to find console targets - [x] Enforce C# 5.0 language version

Issue.Title: Drop the installer
Issue.Description:
The MG installer is causing a high maintenance burden and there are a lot of issues with it. We really don't need to have it anymore if we provide alternatives. That means
- Publish development nugets to a feed. They're published to the TeamCity feed, but IMO we should move to GitHub package feed or MyGet so the publishing of the packages can be done in the CAKE script and finally upgrade from nuget v1. We should also better promote the feed. - Distribute templates with VSIX and as dotnet new template packages (on the aforementioned nuget feed). - Distribute CLI tools as dotnet global tools. - Distribute the Pipeline Tool in some way. Need some discussion for this one, I'm not sure how we best go about this. The Pipeline Tool can use MGCB as a dotnet global tool and will not be tied to any version. We will be able to version it separately. We should make MGCB version configurable in the Pipeline Tool.
cc @tomspilman @cra0zy
Related: #5262

Issue.Title: Switching between Song objects in the MediaPlayer causes them to be played at a reduced volume
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> I'm trying to implement music in my game using the MediaPlayer and Song classes, but I'm running into an issue. The first Song I play will play at the desired volume, no matter how many times I play it. However, as soon as I try playing a different Song, the volume is significantly reduced, even though MediaPlayer.Volume is still set to 1. Even if I try switching back to the original Song, the volume is usually reduced as well. Sometimes the first song will still be at the desired volume after switching back to it, but this seems to occur at random and the volume reduction will eventually occur after calling play on it a few more times. The volume reduction seems to be permanent until I close out and start the game again.
I have tried both MP3 and WAV files, but both run into this issue. This issue does not affect the volume of SoundEffect objects, just Song objects. I tried posting to the forums for a solution, but I was told that this is probably an issue with MonoGame itself and that I should post about it here.
After some experimenting, I found that the problem seems to be related to the ContentManager. Removing all SoundEffect loads from my code fixes the issue, but loading even a single SoundEffect using the ContentManager causes the issue to occur. I'm loading my SoundEffect objects from MP3 files if that's important.
However, this issue occurred even before adding SoundEffect objects to my project, so I'm not sure why removing them now solved the issue. Anyway, SoundEffect objects may or may not be the only source of the issue, but loading SoundEffect objects is the only consistent way of reproducing the issue that I've found.
Here's a simple example where the issue occurs. I've added the following code to a default Windows project. Pressing A or S will cause the song to play at full volume, but then pressing the other button will cause the other song to play at a reduced volume:

Issue.Title: [Question/Proposal] Make DiscardColor writable.
Issue.Description:
Is there any reason ( other than the bug patch here: ) because DiscardColor is different in Debug/Release?
I'm usually working with the Release version but I had to switch back to Debug for some GPU leaks I'm searching and some of my RTs became 'purple-tinted'. Anyways, I think that if there's no ulterior motive DiscardColor should be writable. Right now to get the same results on Debug/Release I have to either: * clear the render target myself to black with an #ifdef DEBUG (which is ugly considering that MG should be multiplatform, yet doesn't get the same results even with a debug/release change) * clear the RT to black without the ifdef (clearing twice, losing performance) * use PreserveContents and clear always (dangerous and prone to errors)
making DiscardColor writable to your desired clear color would result in cleaner code and performant.

Issue.Title: Replace nant scripts with CAKE scripts
Issue.Description:
CAKE is literally made with C# project compilation in mind, as such its much easier to call stuff like `dotnet restore` or `msbuild pack` without having to worry if you properly setuped the location of where the stuff is found on each platform.
CAKE scripts are just C# scripts with some predefined methods, any C# function can be called from them because of this. Its also much easier to read the build script logic as its just C# code.
CC. @tomspilman @Jjagg @dellis1972 @KonajuGames

Issue.Title: Discussion for removing Protobuild and migrating to new(er) style csproj
Issue.Description:
## Tasks
I don't think we should migrate the installer. Instead we should replace it with nugets (and possibly another way to distribute the Pipeline Tool).
To make things usable, but not offer a full replacement we need to fix any failing tests for MGCB on .NET Core, making sure its dependencies all work. Other than that we just need to publish NuGets: - nugets for Core projects - nugets for dotnet new templates - MGCB global tool nuget
We could already publish nuget 1 and 2 without fixing 3, because they use cra0zy's Content.Builder nuget to pull in MGCB (running on .NET Framework).
To fully migrate we need to: - Distribute the pipeline tool someway - Finish DesktopGL VideoPlayer: #6860 (so we can drop the Mac platform) - Provide a VSIX that installs the dotnet new samples (mentioned in #6842)
Bonus: - F# and VB templates - Let the CAKE script upload develop nugets to a feed (myget or GitHub nuget feed)
___________
This issue is for tracking and discussing how to migrate from Protobuild generated project files to sdk-style csproj files.
Related: - #6207 Issue for removing Protobuild - #6650 PR that moves source files for globbing with sdk-style csproj
We will set up pull requests separately to add the csproj for each platform.
________________
Additionally we should look at the following issues once we remove Protobuild: - #5339 #4975 Supporting .NET Standard will be easy - #6137 Support `dotnet build` - #6144 Switch to nugets for dependencies; this would make dependency management so much easier. We could set up a nuget feed on GitHub's [Package Registry]( on teamcity or on myget to have our custom-built stuff hosted. - #6649 can be closed when Protobuild is gone - #5751 and #5192 Publish development builds and pull request builds to a NuGet feed.

Issue.Title: SpriteFont Proposed change to cut out the middle man.
Issue.Description:
Currently sprite font has 2 ways to get at the glyphs and both are round about functionally or optimally.
GetGlyphs() which returns a dictionary but its useless unless you cache that or you will get tons of garbage.
Caching it isn't a real option because spriteBatch drawString can't use your cached dictionary. SpriteFont is also sealed so you can't just encapsulate it if you want to add functionality to your own custom methods.
Then
There is glyphs[] which is readonly and thats fine but whats not fine is that it is an array instead of a dictionary which is like ok... now you can direct access it, but its now the Wrong Type.
With a fat ugly slow method to search for a glyph actually being in the array that is executed in the inner loop of each drawstring. Instead of a dictionary and direct access to it.
Further this call is not accessible **internal int GetGlyphIndexOrDefault(char c)** which sort of makes getting a array even more pointless because the user can't use pointers to access the underlying calls himself from his project. In order to duplicate any speed mitigation the pointer method might give to make up for not having a dictionary.
So in other words whats going on fundamentally is two different ideas are in play and both have the opposite problem and both are basically just acting as middle men (frustration) to what really should be the correct answer to getting at the glyphs.
**public dictionary glyphs;** // or even read only doesn't matter
**what is needed is glyphs to be a dictionary and direct access to it**
(read the very bottom for why its both a speed hit and flexibility problem for extending functionality the way it is now.)
but.. since its not and changing it now **would break it**.
I would like to make the suggestion that one of the two non breaking changes be made to the spritefont class or the better breaking change be made.
**1)** (the superior breaking change) Make glyphs a public dictionary and readonly if necessary, set it in the constructor using GetGlyphs() removing that huge ugly indexing method that checks for a key. replacing it with containsKey.
this would effect all the lines from 263 to 314 essentially removing all but a couple of them and replacing code in the method GetGlyphOrIndex(char c) with something like akin to this.
``
in the constructor glyphs = GetGlyphs(); at the end to set it; in the class declaration as Dictionary<char, Glyph>glyphs; // readonly if requisite
**2)** (the inferior change) Same as the above but make it a addition to the class. leaving the list in also. Then the same steps as discussed above just name it something else. glyphsDictionary or something. Thats double the memory for the glyphs struct as it's two copys, still better then the list. You can still eliminate all that indexing code. ... i would never use the list version given the choice it is inferior and can cause real slow downs when writing a lot of text and it gets much worse as the font size increases comparatively.
**3)** (the semi inferior or possibly the most inferior change) unmark the spritefont class as a final class. public class SpriteFont{ . This option could be slightly better then (2) as one can possibly just new over the class. Essentially mock it up on load to do (1) in roundabout way im not 100% this is possible though. Or You can encapsulate spritefont and wrap the load method and every font that comes in as well as include the additional required dictionary. This is a lot of work that will need repeated in each project and then monogame wont really be changed for it. This will only work on a users custom methods but at least it wont roadblock you at every turn.
Its always been a annoyance every time i write a method or mess with anything that has to do with text and the spritefont class. Well today i was streamlining old methods so i don't have to cache and found it is basically impossible to get around this without deoptimizing spritebatch or caching via a wrapper... and a wrapper wouldn't be the right thing to do. Encapsulating it would be but the damn class is marked final probably for like a .01% speed boost. Which won't mean anything at all if i have to use a array and search that array were i should have a way to directly search a dictionary in the spritefont.
Just in case anyone doesn't get what im saying, a huge font with thousands of characters having to search in a loop that draws those characters on each iteration a character array with thousands of indices takes a shitload longer then just a few hops thru a dictionary and the more characters the worse the situation gets its basically a n^2 situation - random * n vs a dictionary which is basically linear like a log(n) or something basically some linear value * n in time basically its way way less looping the bigger the character array gets.

Issue.Title: Exposing the DrawInstancedPrimitives() instance base index
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below -->
Does anyone have any objections to exposing (as an optional parameter) the instance base index in the call:
`DrawInstancedPrimitives(PrimitiveType primitiveType, int baseVertex, int startIndex, int primitiveCount, int instanceCount)`
Currently the instance base index is hardcoded to 0 inside of the private method `PlatformDrawInstancedPrimitives.`
My proposal is to modify DrawInstancedPrimitives to have the following signature:
`DrawInstancedPrimitives(PrimitiveType primitiveType, int baseVertex, int startIndex, int primitiveCount, int instanceCount, int instanceIndex = 0)`
This will preserve existing usage and behavior but allow you to optionally set a different base index for the instances.
Reason being is that I have a circular buffer of instance data and I want to draw different sections of it without having to also have separate and multiple SetData calls. With this change I can set the data once and have separate draw calls drawing from different sections of the set instance data.

Issue.Title: WebVR and Web Assembly - Possibility in the future
Issue.Description:
Hello there,
This is something to put in your pipe and smoke... Or open discussion.
I have recently been interested in seeing if MonoGame could work with [Blazor]( I have come to the conclusion that I will have to wait for .Net Core support planned in [3.8 Release](
Two of the [Use Cases for Web Assembly]( are Virtual Reality and games, both of which MonoGame would be great for.
I am also interested by a WebVR project called [A-Frame]( which uses ThreeJS and I believe that in the future MonoGame could be used for a similar project built from server-side [Razor Components]( rather than client-side (custom) HTML.
In fact the [demo on the Web Assembly website]( is Tanks! which is a Unity game, built in C# I would assume (unless the Wasm guys converted to C++), so it is realistic to think that MonoGame could also be used with Web Assembly in the same way.
As well as all this, a MonoGame web app built with Blazor could also open up [Electron]( and [Cordova]( as new platforms.
What do you think about all this? Blazor is still experimental so it could be distant future stuff, but still possible.
Luke

Issue.Title: DesktopGL emulates DX9 half pixel offset
Issue.Description:
#### What operating system are you using: - Windows, DesktopGL
There is a rendering difference between the DirectX and OpenGL versions of MonoGame when using the BasicEffect. Because the half pixel offset for OpenGL is not taken into account. While this is taken into account for the SpriteBatch:
Game.Framework/Graphics/GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.cs#L272
This means that anything rendered with the BasicEffect shader is slightly blurry on OpenGL. For example see these two screenshots:
OpenGL: ![text_a](
DirectX: ![text_c](
I think we should give the user some way to know that the half pixel offset should be set by themselves or change the OpenGL shader for the BasicEffect to fix this.
What do you think? I can make a PR once I've gathered more input :).

Issue.Title: Proposition to port math to native implementation
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> I've used MonoGame for about a year, but then decided to switch languages, and ended up on `Rust`. I have missed MonoGame, but I don't really want to leave Rust as it's an amazing programming language. So I came up with the idea to integrate rust with MonoGame, and thought that perhaps the math portion could be ported for ease of use instead of anything too complicated to put into an FFI. I wrote a test and, low and behold, I have great results:
### Matrix.CreateLookAt()
| | MonoGame Implementation | Rust native implementation | |----------------------------|-------------------------|----------------------------| | Time (Ticks) | 17 551 010.16 | 314 615.39 | | Time (MS) | 5273.5 | 94.5 | | Memory (MB) (VS Debugger) | 71.1 | 76.2 | | Memory (MB) (Task Manager) | 68.5 | 69.1 | | CPU% (Task Manager) | 15 ~ 17.5 | 16 ~ 18.5 |
Here is my configuration for reference:
| | Config | |------------------|--------------------------------------------| | Target (Rust) | nightly-x86_64-pc-windows-msvc `--release` | | Target (C#) | Any CPU (Release) | | OS | Windows 10 | | MonoGame version | Latest Stable (3.7.1) | | .Net version | .Net Framework 4.7.1 | | CPU | Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700 CPU @ 3.40GHz | | Ticks Per Second | 3328129 |
So I'm asking, _if_ I were to rewrite alot of the math functions in MonoGame in Rust, would it ever be accepted? (Of course I'd make sure to keep the implementation outputting the same result)
[The source for my tests](
Edit: I later realized, that while rust _does_ compile to many platforms, it doesn't compile to all, so it _may_ not have support for some of the less prominent targets that MonoGame targets. Edit 2: I was actually looking at DateTime for ticks per second, but I was actually using the StopWatch.Frequency ticks per second

Issue.Title: MonoGame 3.7 stops iOS background music on startup with no workaround
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> MonoGame 3.7 has a regression from 3.6 where the iOS audio session category is incorrectly set to `AVAudioSessionCategory.SoloAmbient` in `OpenALSoundController.cs`.
This immediately stops background music and breaks the workaround in issue #735, which was to set the audio session category to `AVAudioSessionCategory.Ambient` in `FinishedLaunching`.
In my opinion, MonoGame should not override the audio category set by the developer, and this code should be deleted.
For one of my games (a party game where audio is essential) I want to use `AVAudioSessionCategory.Playback` with the option `AVAudioSessionCategoryOptions.MixWithOthers` and `SecondaryAudioShouldBeSilencedHint` in order to create an experience where my game sound effects always play (even if the ringer is muted) and my background music only plays if some other background music isn't already playing.
For another of my games (a puzzle game where audio is not essential), I want to use `Ambient` so my sound is silenced when the ringer is muted.
My point is that there isn't a single category that the MonoGame framework should dictate for every game. The framework should leave this setting up to the game developer.
Also note that MonoGame is not setting `AVAudioSessionCategory` when the application is resumed/activated, so I'm able to get the correct behavior if the user switches back to the music app, restarts the music, and switches back to my game. However, I don't consider this a viable workaround.

Issue.Title: Practical problem keyboard input.
Issue.Description: I have been doing quite a bit of text stuff lately and come up on a seemingly unsolvable situation. First problem. The monogame Keyboard class is all messed up big time. **Some keys are straight up missing in the keys enum common ones... Less than, More than, Hyphen, Forward slash ect...** In the not so odd case were i want to press control and use that like a command shortcut with another key like w or m i can maybe get it to work with keyboardstate but if want to do this with a special character at all many of them such as a bracket { or ` < > / [ ] ' ; . **Keyboard state doesn't actually return a shifted case key properly or un-shifted keys right for that matter.** For example here is some test output were i hold shift in all presses notice i get ? instead of / and yet i get , . instead of < >. while pressing the Shifted keys i should get <> ? Un-shifted the keys i should get are this , . / > key[0] LeftShift isCommand True isShift True isNumeric False isCharacter False isSpecialCharacter False > key[1] OemComma isCommand False isShift False isNumeric False isCharacter True isSpecialCharacter True > > key[0] LeftShift isCommand True isShift True isNumeric False isCharacter False isSpecialCharacter False > key[1] OemPeriod isCommand False isShift False isNumeric False isCharacter True isSpecialCharacter False > > key[0] LeftShift isCommand True isShift True isNumeric False isCharacter False isSpecialCharacter False > key[1] OemQuestion isCommand False isShift False isNumeric False isCharacter True isSpecialCharacter True > It returns the upper keys and lower keys without pressing anything else as well essentially whats returned in the array is unmodified by shift. The upper key or lower returned key seems random but constantly shift doesn't modify it at all. **On the other hand.** Text input cannot be used to determine a character pressed when something like the "control" key prevents the event from being raised. **Also when one presses shift and a letter the passed Arguments.Key evaluates to keys.None not Shift which is inconsistent with the other control keys that raise the event.** This leaves you with the only other option being Keyboard GetState. The problem with GetState "Shift" it's borked big time. **Which also means the enum for Keys has a bunch of codes that GetState never ever return.** Can i know 100% the shift key characters are the same for the keys someone else presses on there keyboard even if the upper or lower case was consistently returned. Shift should be modifying which key is returned. **This begs the questions,,,** This lead to... the user hard coding shifted control key characters to some crazy mapping ? Which then begs the question should i expect every keyboard to have the same shift characters above the same keys ? **The impossibility of these two scenarios then combines into something really frustrating...** TextInput as is can't simply replace keyboard input nor can it be used in combination with it properly. I cannot mix the textinput event with the polling as i cannot even see that shift is pressed in the raised event ... So i can't from the raised event method get the keystate to try to see that shift is the control key pressed that way. Remember that the raised event argument for text input returns NONE as the argument when shift is pressed. Conversely i can't poll to the raised method previously fired from my update method to get character keys from text input to hack in as a way to do short cut keys as they don't fire if i hit control, so in some game i can't reliably say control + any special key or control shift any key reliably with either. Even if it was just raised, calling into it is useless when its not raised on control or alt or many others. So no key character or argument will be good anyways other then shift and that actual isn't passed as a argument which means i have to fall back to Keyboard state to see if shift is pressed for any reason ?. Also control arrows insert and many other control keys do not allow the raising of the the text input event at all. So any sort of short cut key via text input is not practically possible in any sort of simple to do way when trying to have a full and simple solution for input and is only semi reliable with keyboardstate. Which leaves exactly no way to detect reliably that the user pressed something like control + / or >. The general user will have to hope their keyboard layout is just like mine and i hard code it with some wacky unshift shift mapping for any kind of command keys i want to add like control * and the next programmer will too. Of course i know they wont all have the same layout. Which im about to do in some limited way in a minute or in some really weird behaviorial way to get around it because i simply can see no other way. E.G. toggle on and off control alt and shift and function keys.

Issue.Title: EXT_framebuffer No Longer Available
Issue.Description:
I've been creating a mostly SpriteBatch 2d game using the DesktopGL template. After recently upgrading my game from MonoGame 3.6 to 3.7 I started receiving reports that players who could play my game using MonoGame 3.6 but could no longer play using MonoGame 3.7.
One of my players has an old Intel Core 2 Duo with integrated graphics. Framebuffer support was provided via the EXT_framebuffer object. As of this PR (#5993) his machine no longer loads the BindFramebufferDelegate, GenFramebufferDelegate, or any of the other EXT functions which eventually leads to a NoSuitableGraphicsDeviceException when trying to call those functions from PlatformApplyRenderTargets in GraphicsDevice.OpenGL.cs.
By bringing back the old EXT loading code, and code in the Framebufferhelper.cs file I was able to compile a MonoGame dll from the develop branch that he could use. Obviously [these changes]( are not suitable for a PR but I was able to prove to myself that these players can still use MonoGame 3.7+ with very minor modifications.
I guess I'm wondering if it was intended to drop support for computers that required the EXT functions (ie 'glBindFramebufferEXT') or if this is a valid issue. If it's valid I can devote more time and attempt to find a real solution for these players that won't break other devices.
Thanks! JC

PullRequest.Title: [OpenGL] Rework Android Framebuffer Support
PullRequest.Description:
OpenTK removal also removed some support for frame buffers on older devices. The old code was a bit of a mess with mutliple FrameBuffer classes each doing the same thing.
This commit reworks the code to have one OpenGL FramebufferHelper and moves all the loading of OpenGL extensions into the OpenGL.cs class where they belong.
As a result GraphicsCapabilites was reworked to use the `Extensions` property on the `GL` class. We also needed to rework when the OpenGL entry points are loaded so ensure we have a current context. If we don't we cannot get the extension strings from opengl since it required a current context.

Issue.Title: Gameloop with fixed frame rate 60 FPS produce unstable timing
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below --> Gameloop with fixed frame rate 60 FPS produce unstable timing. The problem exist very clearly and should also affect low GPU load. Screen's with lower refresh rate might not encounter this problem.
I have identified two problems with the gameloop timing.
1. The gameloop drift and is just below 60 fps. This will make at some point one frame loss (same frame drawn twice) 2. When idle and running Thread.Sleep() timing is cast to (int) making the wait little to short. Because it then do RetryTick: it could make another Thread.Sleep() that will produce a significant long frame because Thread.Sleep() is not exactly and often can't produce very short delays.
**Comment:** I suggest that the multiple Update() for long framerates and IsRunningSlowly could be removed or possible made as optional on/off. It is very confusing and hard to understand that there could be multiple Updates() for one Draw(). (I have comment out the code).
**Solution:** 1. Make the timing a little faster to produce slightly more than 60 FPS. Decrease the sleep wait with one ms. This makes the game at some point produce one extra frame. 2. After Thread.Sleep() don't goto RetryTick() move forward instead.

Issue.Title: [OpenAL] Wrong exception type when binaries are missing
Issue.Code:
Audio namespace is used, MonoGame initialize the static OpenAL bindings and tries to load the library and its entry points, resulting in a EntryPointNotFoundException if the OpenAL binaries are missing.
This is an issue when using third party sound engines and not shipping the OpenAL binaries.
Please also note that this is broken: https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/blob/develop/MonoGame.Framework/SDL/SDLGamePlatform.cs#L72
The DllNotFoundException is no more triggered because the entry points loading have changed and are now throwing EntryPointNotFoundException. And even if GetNativeLibrary() would throw the correct exception type, this code won't be triggered because it happens in the static initializer and no more within the OpenALSoundController constructor.
Related to #6107 and #4717
I think we should move forward with making the Audio`

Issue.Title: Qol its been needed for a long time.
Issue.Description:
Minor Quality of life addition to the Rectangle class. This is a proposal for 3 Rectangle overloads, LocationVector, SizeVector and CenterVector that return Vector2's. These are supplemental to the existing location Property's that return Points of the same name without the word Vector appended at the end.
Motivation...
Today for the umpteenth time i drew a Rectangle.
_Rectangle r = new Rectangle(100,100, 200, 30); spriteBatch.Draw(.., r ,,,);_
Then i drew some text in the rectangle.
_spriteBatch,DrawString( ...... r.Location ,,,,); // This of course would error._
so...
_Vector2 v = new Vector2(r.X, r.Y); spriteBatch,DrawString( ...... v ,,,,);_
The reverse going from Vector2's to Rectangle.Location or Size is annoying and you have to type the cast (int) which i know is sort of a good thing sometimes but honestly in this case not really as it has to be done and will be done anyways,
.
With the proposed addition you would have instead.
_spriteBatch,DrawString( ...... r.LocationVector ,,,,);_
.
Now you might say this isn't a big deal and you are right. I typically have as extension methods ToVector2() and ToPoint() lying around. But ... New people don't as well it gets annoying to always have to add them. Further this amounts to a extra call or pass and typing every time it has to be done.
How many times have these extra lines been written since the begining of xna or monogame,
I submitted a pull request hopefully i did it right.
I know there is cache hit concerns and i didn't try to test for them but i doubt those structs are that big, If you guys approve i would also like to submit the following... On the Vector2 a Point type Return getter. On the Point a Vector2 type Return getter. Typically i name my extensions ToPoint and ToVector
It doesn't and probably shouldn't be a overload (because it should be a explicit method or property call) but something like a ToVector method or property in the point class, (ToPoint in the vector class) would allow many to get rid of extension methods for something that probably should of been added years ago in xna. If nothing else to avoid a extra parameter pass between these calls and to keep the code cleaner.

Issue.Title: MonoGame Android 3.7.0.1708 : Texture2D.GetData corrupts the Texture2D object being read
Issue.Description:
<!-- Write your issue below -->
I've been using CocosSharp successfully with Monogame 3.6. However, when upgrading to 3.7 (or the latest 3.8 dev build), the following code is now corrupting loaded texture data
`var b = new Color[rt.Texture.PixelsHigh * rt.Texture.PixelsWide]; rt.Texture.XNATexture.GetData<Color>(b); `
It appears, rather than just reading out the data, to completely overwrite the texture with a section from a corner of the current screen.
To emphasise: this isn't just a case of it returning the wrong data. The texture being read becomes *corrupted and overwritten* entirely.
It seems the actual data being returned is correct. However, calling SetData on the texture straight afterwards has no effect.

Issue.Title: master branch and v3.7 tag are out of sync
Issue.Description:
# Issue As far as I can understand, the [`master`]( branch is supposed to always point to the latest release tag. In this case, [`v3.7`]( The current git log looks like this: `` Where `upstream` remote is MonoGame and `origin` is my form. It appears that `master` pointed to `v3.6` while that one was the latest release.
It looks like 76cb3d64e and 3d26a001c both supplied the same changes (Update changelog for 3.7 release), and at the same time, but for some reason diverged the history.
## Proposed Resolution `git diff master v3.7` produces no output so the code is at least identical. The only reasonable change I can think of (if any change at all should be done) would be to move the v3.7 tag from 3d26a001c to 0146cf60f. Looking at the previous releases, the tags were always assigned to master once it merged the latest release changes. So this is what should have happened at least.
That can obviously be a bad idea if anyone (foolishly) has added commits on their fork to the v3.7 tag.
I'm not sure how big of a deal this is, but I thought it would be worth bringing up.

Issue.Title: Game will not close using window close button (Unique Situation)
Issue.Description:
I am having an issue with the window/game freezing when clicking the window's X close button.
Hold onto your hats. I am going to try to explain this the best that I can and I am sure that the issue has to do with the way I am doing this and using **MonoGame**. I just don't know how to fix it.
I am creating a game engine that has a **plugin type architecture**. The whole idea is that my engine will be able to load implementations of various parts of my engine, by loading a DLL library at runtime that contains those implementations.
Doing this will let me (or other developers) actually take only certain parts of my engine and swap out the implementation with another one as long as they adhere to the interfaces provided. This shared library that contains all the interfaces is in its own library. The implementation library is another separate project.
This implementation library would be the **plugin** for the underlying core of the engine.
So the way it would work would be this. Developer John Doe would create a C# windows project running .NET Framework 4.5. This project is the **game** and would have a reference to my engine library for use. John Doe would then create a C# library project using .NET Framework 4.5 under the same solution. For this library project he would reference my **engine core** library that contains all of the interfaces that he has to adhere to for my game engine to use the new implementation library he is creating.
This implementation library is loaded during runtime by my game engine. Throughout my engine I use a static class to pull a particular object implementation from the assembly that was loaded and inject it where its needed.
---
Example Of Usage:
I create the windows app, reference the game engine. Create another library project called **MyImplementationA** and I reference my engine core library. In the implementation library I just created I would create a class called **TextureA** that implements the **ITexture** interface that comes from the core library. I write my **implementation** for **TextureA**.
Now I create another implementation library project called **MyImplementationB** and reference my engine core library just like above. But this time I create a class called **TextureB** that implements the **ITexture** interface and write its implementation.
Now I have 2 assemblies. **MyImplementationA.dll** implements **TextureA** and **MyImplementationB.dll** implements **TextureB**. Now at this point I can just simply load either library up and I get that particular functionality.
Doing this means that if **DevA** wants to use **MonoGame** to do some of the work for the engine under the hood, and **DevB** wants to use **SDL**, it will all operate the same. Or they can use something else if they wanted.
Now everything I explained above works like a charm. Its pretty awesome and I am very happy with the results.
But.....my implementation that I am using for testing my game engine is MonoGame. This means in the implementation library it uses the **Game** class. I am only assuming that this is the cause because I technically am loading the **MonoGame** **Game** during runtime from another assembly. Could this be the issue? I know that it must be obviously running in the same process as my game engine, because my engine is the one loading the assembly so that means that **MonoGame** under the hood would be running in the same process as my engine.
One thing I tried to do is have my engine get access to the **Game.Exit()** method so that way I could try to exit the game and close the window in code. This does not work. It just throws a **System.NullReferenceException** at the line of code where **Game.Run()** is used. This tells me that at this point **Game** has been disposed of, garbage collected, and doesn't exist anymore. So I guess it is **"Exiting"**, but not closing the window. And with that I think the reason the window doesn't close is because it isn't **"attached"** to **MonoGame** anymore.
I know this situation is unique and there are probably a lot of unknowns, but at this point I don't know what to do about the issue and really don't want this to prevent me from using **MonoGame** or any other libraries.
If you need more information or have some questions for me to help you understand, don't hesitate to ask.
Any help would greatly be appreciated!!
---

<!-- Write your issue below -->
I am compiling a sample project in the latest version of MonoGame with plans to port over an existing XNA project. In polling the controllers that are active, I have the following code (MaxPlayers defined as 8)
// Update previous gamepad states and store the latest state for(int padIndex = 0; padIndex < Global.MaxPlayers; ++padIndex) { m_gamePadPrevious[padIndex] = m_gamePadCurrent[padIndex]; m_gamePadCurrent[padIndex] = GamePad.GetState(padIndex);

Issue.Title: Add interfaces for high level objects like SpriteBatch and GraphicsDeviceManager
Issue.Description:
## Problem
Currently it is very difficult to test code which depends on certain parts of Monogame, such as `SpriteBatch` as you cannot mock the object making your tests require actual instances of SpriteBatch (which in turn requires GraphicsDeviceManager instance etc), and while there are some test classes internally in MG source they are not really exposed externally.
Due to this the only way to get around it at the moment is to create your own inherited version which tries to counter the underlying behaviour from base classes, and also use some pragmas to switch between test code and real code which is VERY bad as my source code shouldn't need to know it is being tested, and would end up with some test specific code being bundled into my actual game source.
I am also wanting to make use of Dependency Injection which is far better when using interfaces as you are able to bind interfaces to implementations far easier than binding concrete classes to themselves.
There is also the problem that because of not using interfaces a lot of internal MG code is having to use partial classes or other tricks to have platform specific code run, i.e winRT, SDL related code for `GraphicsDeviceManager`. A lot of this could be avoided if interfaces were adopted for surface API contracts and then composition used within platform specific packages to bundle the specific optimizations/required.
## Solution
Wherever possible on the surface API (ones consumers often use) add interfaces which expose the public methods/properties and use that as the contract on exposed MG code.
For example if we had `ISpriteBatch` we could mock this within a test without needing any form of underlying graphics device etc, also this would mean that we could easily provide our own implementation if needed and, this would also mean that all code depending on this only cares about the surface API contract, not the underlying implementation behavior, so if you needed to make platform specific optimizations you can do so without effecting the consumer too much, as the contract doesnt change, just the underlying implementations.
The only down side to adding interfaces and using them as the contract around the framework would be the impact on using interface methods (akin to virtual methods) vs direct calls, which depending on throughput can create an almost non existent performance difference.
Going forward this allows users to do more with the library in varying scenarios from testing, plugins, extensibility, dependency injection etc, and makes the framework easier to chunk up and move towards a more singular `MonoGame.Core` which could contain all truly shared functionality and interfaces, and just have platform specific implementations, ultimately making it more flexible going forward.
## Other info
If you have resharper this is not too difficult to do as you can literally extract interfaces quickly for most objects, then just find all usages of that concrete class and replace it wherever needed with an interface.
If there are any performance critical internal pieces by all means skip putting interfaces in, but for surface API there is virtually no downside other than the overhead of implementing it.

Issue.Title: New SpriteFont Kerning list can not be smaller than Character list
Issue.Code:
<StructLayout(LayoutKind.Sequential)> Structure KerningPair Public wFirst As Short Public wSecond As Short Public iKernelAmount As Integer End Structure
<DllImport("gdi32.dll", SetLastError:=True, CallingConvention:=CallingConvention.Winapi)> Public Function GetKerningPairs(hdc As IntPtr, nPairs As Integer, <MarshalAs(UnmanagedType.LPArray, SizeParamIndex:=1)> <Out()> pairs() As KerningPair) As Integer End Function
<DllImport("gdi32.dll")> Private Function SelectObject(hdc As IntPtr, hObject As IntPtr) As IntPtr End Function
Public Function GetKerningPairs(Font As Drawing.Font) As IList(Of KerningPair) Using Graphics As Drawing.Graphics = Drawing.Graphics.FromHwnd(IntPtr.Zero) Graphics.PageUnit = Drawing.GraphicsUnit.Pixel
Dim Pairs() As KerningPair Dim Hdc As IntPtr = Graphics.GetHdc Dim HFont As IntPtr = Font.ToHfont Dim Old As IntPtr = SelectObject(Hdc, HFont) Try Dim NumPairs As Integer = GetKerningPairs(Hdc, 0, Nothing) If (NumPairs > 0) Then Pairs = New KerningPair(NumPairs - 1) {} NumPairs = GetKerningPairs(Hdc, NumPairs, Pairs) Return Pairs Else Return Nothing End If Finally Old = SelectObject(Hdc, Old) End Try End Using End Function `
Issue.Description:
When programmatically creating a new spritefont, the List of Kernings cannot be smaller than the character list, this is odd, since not all characters need to have kernings when working with for example windows fonts.
If the Kerning list is smaller than character list you'll get this exception : System.ArgumentOutOfRangeException: 'Index was out of range. Must be non-negative and less than the size of the collection. Parameter name: index'
I've tracked it down to this line and the lines below it :
I'm using windows' "GetKerningPairs" and how i understand it to work, is that the font has a list of kernings it will apply to a string of characters when it checks that string with the kerning list. So each character could have multiple kernings with multiple other characters.
But the way it's in MonoGame is strange, in the SpriteFont source code we can see that each character in a new SpriteFont has to have a kerning and only one.
This is how i get the kerningpairs of a font in windows (note that it's in vb.net):
`` Doing it this way will give kernings where one of the two pairs appear multiple times.
With the way kernings are used in MonoGame it seems better to use Vector3.Zero in the entire kerning list otherwise you'll be limited to one pair for each character, which have made it difficult to render text intuitively with a new SpriteFont, we also have to keep in mind that spacing is still applied too.

Issue.Title: Make MonoGame.net website use HTTPS instead of HTTP
Issue.Description:
There are many reasons to use HTTPS. It's not just about securing sites with login information. Sites using plain HTTP are prone to hijacking. It wouldn't be good if a malicious man-in-the-middle decided to inject ads or malware onto MonoGame.net. [Some ISPs also inject unwanted content into HTTP sites.](
Services such as [Let's Encrypt]( make getting started with HTTPS fairly easy to do.
Once MonoGame.net has HTTPS support, it's also important to redirect users to the HTTPS version of the site if they load the HTTP version, to ensure that the users are using the secure version.

Issue.Title: XML doc request
Issue.Description:
Would it be possible to include XML schema in the MonoGame documentation for the serializable classes(including Reflection and Helpers)?
While the helper classes would need to be manually updated (include a comment to ensure changes are reflected in the documentation), the reflective serializer can utilize xsd.exe to generate the proper schema and wrap it with the appropriate tags.
I have concluded that attempting to solve #4792, the only solutions utilizing XmlReader.Create() instead of XmlTextReader, forces any solution that exists to be in exponential time.
While I could mitigate the problems, by eliminating already read elements, I do not feel like my approach is the appropriate solution, given my solution only works for basic cases. I am opting for option "B" to the original problem. Give the user the needed feedback to correct the situation. Instead of only informing the user the the expected element is missing; Give the user the expected element AND a reference to the expected schema. Even if the proper schema is not available; This would inform the user of the out-of-order elements and the opportunity to correct them, instead of only informing of the missing element.
I hope to provide a PR with this issue, to inform the user the element is out of order(already in the works), I also wish to return a reference the appropriate schema to be utilized when implementing the class(Hence the Issue).

Issue.Title: UWP, XamlGame<T> construction
Issue.Description:
<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build installer from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue below -->
Hi!
I'd like to discuss another possible way to initialize a game object for a XAML UWP application.
Now there is a static initializer `MonoGame.Framework.XamlGame<T>.Create(...)` that takes care of the construction of the `Game` class. With this logic, it isn't possible to inject in a "clear" way some dependencies, since the default constructor is called: `var game = new T();`.
What I'd like to propose as a pull request, if you agree with me, is: - Doing nothing to XamlGame<T>.Create(...), in avoid breaking everything and to keep projects templates as they are - Add an overload to that Create method that takes a "gameConstructor Func<T>", to be called like this: `var game = gameConstructor();` in the Create method.
In that way, the final user will initialize its UWP implementation of the game like this: `var game = MonoGame.Framework.XamlGame<MyGameClass>.Create(launchArguments, Window.Current.CoreWindow, swapChainPanel, () => new MyGameClass(dep1, dep2...));`
_Side note:_ Considering that the class requires the `T : Game` to have a default constructor, by adding this overload I ask anyway to mantain a default constructor, although it couldn't be necessary.
**Why I need to inject dependencies in my game?** Consider I have the same Game class for different platforms. My game class needs an `IStringsProvider`, an `IAchievementsManager`, an `IStoreGateway`: I would implement those differently for each platform. To me, each specific platform will have only need to construct a new game with its correct implementations. This is a real case, I have game published for Android and for UWP with this logic.
What do you think? (If you agree I could do the pull request) Thanks.

<!-- # Please make sure that the issue is present in the # develop branch of MonoGame before reporting # # You can download the development build insaller from: # -->
<!-- Write your issue bellow --> #### Overview: Took a break from gameDev with a work trip a few weeks back and found that none of my home computers (all windows 10) and my 3 alpha testers (also windows 10) can use a GamePad.
Tried it both on 3.6 and 3.7.
The gamePad ".isConnected" is true or false depending on if the controller is plugged in or not for most of the devices, except the xbox one controllers no longer light up or say connected. Issue.Title: Float textures for OpenGL ES 3.0
Issue.Code: new RenderTarget2D(GraphicsDevice, 2048, 2048, false, SurfaceFormat.Single, DepthFormat.Depth24); `
Issue.Description:
MonoGame currently does not support `SurfaceFormat.Single` for GL ES 3.0. I opened this issue in response to a topic on the forums:
In OpenGL ES 2.0 float textures are supported through the [`OES_texture_float`]( extension, but only in the alpha channel. Since `SurfaceFormat.Single` is defined as a float in the red channel we can't support it in GL ES 2.0.
In OpenGL ES 3.0 things work just like in OpenGL, so things should just work if MG did exactly the same thing as in DesktopGL. Currently an `UnsupportedOperationException` is thrown. The user reporting this issue in the forum topic mentioned the following line causes the exception: ``
We should investigate where this exception is thrown so we can prevent throwing it under OpenGL ES 3.0. The docs should mention that `SurfaceFormat.Single` is not supported for OpenGL ES 2.0.
This does raise the question if we should actually support OpenGL ES 3.0+ only features on mobile, since it's not portable. In this case it's zero-effort though, so I'm all for it :)

Issue.Title: Possible bug: MouseState not always changing after calling Mouse.SetPosition
Issue.Description:
I need to capture the mouse cursor within game's window area to prevent accidental clicks outside of it, which gamers find very annoying when that happens.
Unfortunately, I can't find any dedicated MonoGame's functionality for that (not letting the mouse to go outside of the game window / delta-based mouse input), so I came up with a solution involving setting the mouse position to the center of the window.
Unfortunately 2, there seems to be a rare bug that causes the position reported in the mouse state to be always different than the position I set (so my cursor is always "going somewhere" without me even touching the mouse, it resets when I move the mouse again).
My operating system is Windows 10. Not sure if it happened on older Windows versions.
Here's the screenshot from Visual Studio with the watches that show the values of variables used to compute the delta. I've set this up without touching the mouse not to spoil the result. The expected behavior is that the next time I hit the breakpoint, the X value in the mouse state should be changed to the mouseMidX's value and the deltas should be 0. It doesn't happen until I move the mouse slightly, then it returns to the expected behavior. So far, the bug appears to happen randomly.
I'm not aware of any other way to do it in MonoGame, which is a shame, because that kind of mouse control is absolutely essential for 2d aiming or FPP look.

Issue.Title: Remove Protobuild
Issue.Description:
There are so many better ways of organizing the repo without using Protobuild: - using shared projects - using the new csproj format + few wildcards - using the old csproj format + few wildcards
For the first pass we would just need to generate all the .csproj files, this way we won't be changing anything for the build system, and afterwards we could slowly do modifications over time with smaller changes.
Alternatively we could make it only generate the MonoGame.Framework and MonoGame.Framework.Net projects, while everything else is made of static projects.
