Issue.Title: OpenGL project switches to full screen mode when fullscreen flag is set to off / false
Issue.Description:
I am currently using MG 3.7.0.1245 (pretty recent dev build) for an OpenGL project on Windows 10 using VS 2017.
On my laptop, I am setting graphics mode 1920x1080 with fullscreen *off* (GraphicsDevice.IsFullScreen = false).
1920x1080 is my Windows 10 / laptop screen resolution.
I previously had no app.manifest file (the project settings had Manifest set to "embed manifest with default settings), however, with that setting, I was having issues with the DPI scaling on my laptop and the screen size / backbuffer.
Without the project app.manifest, setting the mode to 1920x1080 with fullscreen *off* worked fine i.e. I would get a windowed output.
However, I have since created an app.manifest file which has the dpiAware = true entry. This fixes my DPI scaling problem, however now, when I set the mode to 1920x1080 and have fullscreen set to *off*, the app still launches in fullscreen. If I change the app mode to another resolution e.g. 800x600 (which is different from my screen resolution of 1920x1080), then it displays correctly in windowed mode.
So the issue seems to be setting a mode that matches the screen resolution (in this case 1920x1080) and having dpiAware = true. When those 2 things are aligned, the fullscreen flag seems to be ignored and it sets the app to fullscreen anyways.
Unless I am mistaken, the app should always be in windowed mode when the isFullScreen flag is set to false, even if the window size matches the screen resolution.

Issue.Title: Proposal to switch away from conditional builds
Issue.Description:
As of right now, Monogame uses conditional inclusion of source files to support multiple platforms. `MonoGame.Framework` for exaple is compiled as a single monolithic assembly, which is different for each target platform.
To help with: - Transitioning Monogame to .net standard for cross platform logic, since PCLs are deprecated - Targeting .net core where posible - Switching to using nuget for dependencies #6144 - Reducing build times - Maybe even get rid of protobuild, since Visual Studio for Mac uses MSBuild, and MSBuild itself is open source and available for Linux too
I propose monogame should: - Have projects containing only cross platform logic, which would generate .net standard assemblies - Have platform specific code in separate, platform specific projects, which would reference the cross platform assemblies via project reference - Use the bait and switch Nuget pattern to have nuget and msbuild include the appropriate assemblies for the target platform when Monogame is included as a dependency - Use Nuget packages' `runtime` folder and runtime IDs to package any OS dependent assemblies Monogame needs to run ([see here for details](

Issue.Title: EffectParameter names vary because of build target
Issue.Description:
As mentioned in PR #6146 the name of an `EffectParameter` may be different for OpenGL builds than for all others, if it's a `TextureSampler`. But that is a problem, as @tomspilman already mentioned since the name of a parameter should be the primary way to fetch it, not the index in the `EffectParameter[]` in the `EffectParameterCollection`.
I've prepared a GitHub repo that should demonstrate this issue and can be a point where to start debugging. I've not added a .gitignore file, so everyting's in there.
I've tested it with: MonoGame 3.7.0.1232 MonoGame 3.7.0.960 MonoGame 3.6.0.1598 It's the same everywhere.
Disclaimer :) Maybe I'm doing something wrong here. There are many ways to declare a `TextureSampler`, but I think the shader is alright. It definitely is connected to the sampler declaration, since if you declare it like this: `sampler2D FirstSampler : register(s0);` it works! But you can't use the new notation to fetch texels and you're stuck with `tex2D`. Sure is an option, but the bug is there nevertheless.
BTW... When passing two textures, there is some odd behavior that I have documented in this repository (including images). Maybe someone can take a look and decide whether it's worth pursuing or not.

Issue.Title: Improve OpenAssetImporter
Issue.Description:
Currently the `OpenAssetImporter` is crippled to only expose features that the old XNA `FbxImporter` and `XImporter` supported. So for example we only expose 4 different texture types in `MaterialContent`:
- Texture (aka Diffuse) - Transparency - Specular - Bump
However AssImp supports like 12 different types of defined texture maps and even custom ones.
Same sort of thing exists for material properties where we only expose a few... but some useful ones like 'IsTwoSided` is not exposed.
I think we have two paths:
A) Just add the extra stuff as `OpaqueData` and not worry. B) Set a `XnaCompatible` flag to `OpenAssetImporter` when called from the `FbxImporter`.
If you use the `OpenAssetImporter` or `FbxImporter` let me know what you think.

PullRequest.Title: OpenAssetImporter Improvements and FbxImporter Unit Tests
PullRequest.Description:
This PR is related to
I extended the material support in `OpenAssetImporter` to export all the material features exposed by AssImp. This breaks anyone that uses `OpenAssetImporter` directly... but hopefully for the better.
`FbxImporter` and `XImporter` now pass a flag to `OpenAssetImporter` asking for XNA compatibility returning just the material properties expected under XNA 4.0. I added a unit test for `FbxImporter` to help prove that nothing has changed or is broken.
It is debatable if this is necessary or if we're ok passing additional non-XNA material properties from `FbxImporter` and `XImporter` .

Issue.Title: Custom name for Content project in msbuild pipeline is not configurable
Issue.Description:
In XNA it is possible to rename a content project. This would place the resulting binaries in a directory with the name of your choosing. In MonoGame you can rename the .mgcb file or rename the directory it resides in, but the msbuild system will always copy it to a directory named Content in the target directory.
Firstly this is a problem because it differs from XNA. Secondly this is a problem because you have no way to separate the target directory of multiple content projects in a single project. This can very easily lead to file name collisions.

Issue.Title: Support for double-precision floats
Issue.Description:
For games that deal with large scales, double-precision (64-bit) float support is very nice to have.
* Many large-scale games on custom engines use `double`, such as Minecraft, Star Citizen, Elite: Dangerous, Space Engineers, Grand Theft Auto, the Unigine game engine, and likely many many more.
* Few game engines currently support `double` for legacy reasons back when CPUs weren't able to calculate `double` quickly, however, modern FPUs and SIMDs can handle double-precision without issues. Some can even use quadruple-precision at high speeds.
* Some large scale games, like Kerbal Space Program, use `double` for math and convert back to `float` for local positioning of objects, because it uses the Unity game engine which uses single-precision floats. This isn't efficient or ideal, is difficult to program, and ends up being buggy in the end. It isn't too practical for multiplayer, either.
One way of doing this is by creating an abstract type `real_t` instead of `float` which can be `typedef` to either `float` or `double`. This is ideal because it would allow MonoGame to compile with either `float` or `double` support with minimal effort. This is how Godot is implementing it:
It may also be worthwhile to create structs like `Vector3f` and `Vector3d` which are always `float` or `double` respectively, so that creators of games can choose a fixed type to use with their scripting.

Issue.Title: Game not running/launching when using 3.6+
MonoGame.Utilities's Operations.Malloc is not threadsafe, and so Texture2D.FromStream isn't
Issue.Description:
Been suffering from random failures to load pictures into textures, which ultimately were tracked down to exceptions while trying to index the dictionary used by Operations.Malloc.
On inspecting it became clear that there isn't any protection against concurrent writes to the dictionary tracking allocations, and so this method would be unsafe to call from multiple threads at once, but Texture2D.FromStream assumes that the image loading can be done from any thread and doesn't dispatch to the UI thread until actually creating the texture, leading to multiple calls into malloc at once during texture loading. As a temporary fix I've modified my fork to do the image loading on the UI thread too- this is not ideal but prevents crashes.
Replication is somewhat difficult- you have to spawn multiple threads and try to load textures on them, and sometimes it will crash. I could put together a sample project if needed, although I think the problem is fairly visible to inspection- there's an object called "_lock" in Operations.cs, but nothing ever uses it, and in the absence of any locking concurrent writes to a dictionary are incorrect.

Issue.Title: SdlGameWindow.Handle returns SDL Handle, instead of Win32 Handle as expected
Issue.Code: csharp var win32Handle = Process.GetCurrentProcess().MainWindowHandle; // 0x0000000000b50646 var sdlHandle = this.Window.Handle; // 0x0000025f1ba0ccc0 var windowType = this.Window.GetType().FullName; // "Microsoft.Xna.Framework.SdlGameWindow" `
Issue.Description:
In XNA as well as in the [`WinFormsGameForm`]( [`GameWindow.Handle`]( returns the Win32-Handle of the window.
That can be cast to a `System.Windows.Forms.Control` (of course, that's impossible as we don't use WinForms), but also passed to Win32-APIs such as `ShowWindow(IntPtr hWnd, int nCmdShow)` in `user32.dll`, or the linux equivalents.
However, at the moment it [returns the SDL-Handle]( which is quite useless at first glance, since one can only pass it to SDL-functions.
Those SDL-Functions can't be used, since the [SDL Interface is not exposed](
Proposal:
- Change `SdlGameWindow.Handle` to return a Win32-Handle by expected. This can be retrieved using [`SDL_GetWindowWMInfo`]( and create an explicit Property `SdlGameWindow.SdlHandle` where the old `_handle` will be returned. Problem: `SdlGameWindow` is (of course) marked internal, so a user wouldn't be able to access it without reflection.
- Give users a way to call SDL-functions such as [Sdl.Show()]( so we one can use this property with copying the SDL2.cs to the game-project.
In my opionion, a mix of these approaches would be best (expose the Sdl2-Interface somehow, *and* add the extra `SdlHandle`-Property).
Just for reference:
``

Issue.Title: Lack of OpenAL DLLs shouldn't be fatal.
Issue.Description:
I don't want to use OpenAL audio at all, so I don't think I should be required to distribute the libraries related to it.
It would be better to make me choose whether I want to initialize the MonoGame audio (and load the libs) or not. It's done in the runtime anyway, so this functionality should be easy to add (e.g. static `Game.InitializeAudio = false;` before creating the Game instance), especially that my use case isn't really isolated. I believe that many gamedevs choose FMOD or Wwise over solutions native to engines/frameworks simply because their sound designers are used to these tools.
I get that it might be a minor issue to most people, but there's no need to be forced to distribute two audio frameworks simultaneously (which is one of many reasons I don't really like Unity) and it seems to be easy to avoid in case of MonoGame. Give us more freedom :)

Issue.Title: Leveraging C# 7.2 'reference semantics with value types' in future?
Issue.Description:
Based on my shallow understanding it should be a good little performance booster? I was wondering if it's worth tracking this for some 4.x+ release. Obviously it would limit code to C# 7.2+ compilers.
> An advantage to using value types is that they often avoid heap allocations. The corresponding disadvantage is that they are copied by value. This tradeoff makes it harder to optimize algorithms that operate on large amounts of data. New language features in C# 7.2 provide mechanisms that enable pass-by-reference semantics with value types. If you use these features wisely you can minimize both allocations and copy operations. This article explores those new features.
> These enhancements to the C# language are designed for performance critical algorithms where memory allocations can be critical to achieving the necessary performance. You may find that you don't often use these features in the code you write.

Issue.Title: Content pipeline Visual Studio integration
Issue.Description:
Towards the end of #4796 the [idea was broached]( of integrating content management into the IDE itself rather than having a separate tool, but the conversation was muddied since the original issue was essentially a complaint about the existence of a content pipeline in the first place.
The thing that strikes me about that proposition is it's essentially how XNA worked - within your XNA project you had a Content project (similar to but not the same as the MonoGame setup, where the Content folder contains a magic file called Content.mgcb) to which you added your assets directly; the conversion to XNB files happened at compile-time, and the Visual Studio properties pane let you configure the same things as the Pipeline Tool's properties pane.
Is the separate tool just for the benefit of users on non-Windows platforms, or are there benefits to having a separate tool for everyone? Is it possible to have the convenient Visual Studio-integrated content pipeline on those platforms which support it and the separate MonoGame tool elsewhere?

Issue.Title: [Android] Viewport size issues
Issue.Code:
GraphicsDevice.Viewport issues when using fullscreen or immersive mode.
It seems that the viewport is too small and offset'd by the size of the action bar.
This is because the initial Viewport size is based on CurrentDisplayMode, which uses AndroidGameView.GameView.Width / Height, while PreferredBackbufferWidth / Height gets their value from ClientBounds (set from Context.Resources.DisplayMetrics).
On my device, AndroidGameView.GameView is 600x1024 while Context.Resources.DisplayMetrics is 600x976.
I believe this is due to MonoAndroidGameView being created after the Context is queried for the display size and then returns values for non-fullscreen mode. Potential fix would be to initialize ClientBounds`

Issue.Title: Rectangle bugs
Issue.Description:
*Rectangle.IsEmpty* and *Rectangle.Empty* should be corrected, as using either of these could lead to bugs via false negatives.
The current implementation is: `` I realize this is legacy dragged along from XNA but regardless, its still incorrect and bugged against what should be expected behavior.
This also applies to the *Rectangle.Empty* constant which really shouldn't be labeled the definitive state of an empty Rectangle. As mentioned above, the X and Y positions have no context in whether it is empty and only a width **or** height of 0 indicate emptiness. Issue.Title: Expose keyDown / keyUp events in GameWindow class.
Issue.Description:
Currently the `GameWindow` class expose a `TextInput` event to allows the creation of text boxes and other similar UI events. However, this event only fires when characters are typed, **and common function buttons like backspace or delete don't trigger this event**.
To provide full functionality to a textbox like UI control, **we currently need to emulate the behavior** by checking the key state in the `Keyboard` class, in an `Update()` loop. However, this emulation is not perfect, because even if implement it to emulate the keyboard delays and repeat speed, if the user hit rapidly the backspace stroke (for example), as the update loop is running, by default, at 60hz, **we may miss some keystrokes**.
**This gives the end user a laggy experience**. I suggest to implement the `KeyDown` and `KeyUp` events as well (and from what I see in `OpenTKGameWindow`, they're already used, it's just a matter of exposing them) in the `GameWindow` so the user of the framework could have a finer grained control of the keyboard, and would not have to rely on sort of emulation to provide erasing capabilities to a text box.

Issue.Title: [DirectX] Reach profile can crash on DX10+ GPUs that don't support intermediate feature levels
Issue.Description:
Some GPUs support DirectX 10_0 feature level, but don't support all 9_x feature levels.
In my case, a laptop GPU supports only 10_0 & 9_1 (no 9_2 & 9_3). Shaders that use ps_4_0_level_9_3 will crash on that laptop when using _Reach_ GraphicsProfile. They work with other GPUs under Reach and they work on this laptop when using HiDef profile.
Problem is that MG tries to make a device with feature level 9_3 first when GraphicsProfile is set to Reach. When that fails 9_1 device is created, although 10_0 is supported. This results in crash when trying to use 9_3 shaders.
Proposed solution by @Jjagg is that MonoGame should always try to create a device with the highest possible feature level to prevent this issue. Even under Reach.

Same example in WindowsGL works correctly.
After some research, I found that SharpDX.XAudio2 [constructor]( was throwing an exception with the following message:
`HRESULT: [0x80040154], Module: [Unknown], ApiCode: [Unknown/Unknown], Message: Unregistered Class`
I tried to find a solution using the SharpDX currently used by monogame without success.
Then I followed the next steps:
I upgraded MonoGame.Framework.Windows to SharpDx 4.0 Upon compiling it gave 3 or 4 errors very easy to fix (RawBool instead of Bool and a missing argument in Reberb) After compiling and running again, it gives more initialization exceptions, but this time in the [MasteringVoice]( , apparently, it doesn't like being passed a deviceID = 0 I removed the last three arguments, and left the constructor as `new MasteringVoice(Device);`
Compiled again, and it worked!, sound was playing!
So in order to fix the problem, it's a matter of upgrading to SharpDX 4.0 and adjusting the MasteringVoice constructor.
Btw, I tried removing deviceId argument from MasteringVolume with SharpDX 2.6.3 but it didn't work. Given that SharpDX 4.0 is a significant milestone and it seems there's no big hurdles upgrading monogame to SharpDX, I would ask to consider upgrading soon.

Issue.Description:
Going by the description, the MonoGame.Framework.Portable nuget package should be a bait and switch PCL, however it does not have the same API surface as the platform specific ones, and as a matter of fact is not a bait and switch PCL at all (look at MonoGame\NuGetPackages\MonoGame.Framework.Portable.nuspec and the only target is the PCL platform moniker - nuget packages targeting multiple platforms should be structured [like this]( This includes the latest prerelease version as well.
To test, create a monogame project (I am using the Monogame UWP template), and a PCL project, then reference the PCL from the main project.
Add the MonoGame.Framework.Portable package to the PCL project and try to build: you'll get a conflict because both the PCL nuget package and the UWP try to copy their different versions of Monogame.Framework.dll to the same location.
Try adding the PCL nuget to both projects instead of the platform specific one and MonoGame.Framework is not present anymore.
This means the only way of sharing code in a game targeting different platforms is to use a shared project like in the template, which is not at all good practice.

Hello,
I've been patching the Pipeline tool to accept linked files.
Some notes:
* The patch includes @vchelaru 's PR to support links in MGCB with the addition of links to 'copied' files, which were missing (I'm so lame at git that I had to copy them manually to my repository) * When deleting linked files, "LINKED TO" appears in the delete list to show they're linked files. (In VS it appears in the log, but I didn't find a log to include it, and it was very confusing when files were not added without apparent reason). The message does not appear when copying (unless I messed up)
Unfortunately using git when other human users are around is too much for an old git like me (pun intended) and I've set up a project and uploaded all the changes there (that's the most I can do in git without spending an hour looking at documentation). Here it is: (I don't even know if this is the link I should be posting XD )
It also mixes several different features in a single PR, which shouldn't be done, and some variable names might not be congruent with the coding style of the project. Not even mentioning tabs and spaces and formatting :)
Finally, I have no idea at all of the Pipeline tool, so some pieces of code are more a dirty hack than a nice piece for a PR. I just hope the repository is useful to somebody with more Pipeline tool knowledge to integrate it. On the bright side I've overcommented some parts to give the 'integrator' a clue of what I'm doing :)

Issue.Title: Fix or remove `checkedRect` from Texture2D Set/GetData
Issue.Description:
The `checkedRect` change in Texture2D Set/GetData is broken for compressed texture formats:
It doesn't consider that for compressed formats there is a minimum mipmap size that must be enforced. So it passes the incorrect rectangle down to methods for setting the texture data.
IMO we sure purge this `checkedRect` business entirely from the code base.
In particular the removal of calling SetData with a `null` rectangle is likely a performance hit.
I am willing to bet that for example `GL.TexSubImage2D` is slower than `GL.TexImage2D` when setting texture data. Same with the methods under DirectX when the full texture level was being set instead of a sub-rectangle of the texture surface.
IMO we need to refactor all this to restore the old behavior for `null` rectangles and fix the checking when a rectangle is passed to consider compression needs.

Issue.Title: Purge calls of GL.GenerateMipmap from Texture constructors
Issue.Description:
In `Texture2D` in particular it calls `GL.GenerateMipmap` in some form to fill out the mip map chain.
This is wrong.
`GL.GenerateMipmap` literally means "generate mip maps from the level 0 data now". It reads each pixel of the level 0 data and filters it down to generate mips. Depending on the target platform on the CPU or the GPU.
It should be painfully obvious that doing this on a empty texture is a waste of time.
Also you cannot call `GL.GenerateMipmap` on compressed textures as GL will not auto generate mips for compressed formats. It would require GL to compress the texture at runtime which it does not do. So currently this fails for compressed formats.
Versions of MonoGame from just 6 months ago didn't call `GL.GenerateMipmap` at all:
~~So either A:~~
- ~~We stop calling `GL.GenerateMipmap` and do nothing for mipmaps on construction (which I don't know is correct).~~
Or B:
- We correctly define mip levels on a texture by writing a loop and calling `GL.CompressedTexImage2D` or `GL.TexImage2D` for each level.

Issue.Title: Fix Texture2D.ValidateParams() for Compressed Formats
Issue.Description:
The current implementation of `Texture2D.ValidateParams()` is broken for compressed formats (likely for all... but in particular PVRTC). This is a critical issue that needs to be resolve ASAP as it makes MonoGame useless for most game development.
It doesn't consider bits per pixel or that there is a min size for some mip levels. You can see my findings here:
We need to add some specific unit tests for setting/getting data on compressed formats including data on every mip level.

Issue.Title: [VR] Add a method to get native Ptr from a texture
Issue.Description:
Hi,
I'm working on a VR implementation with Monogame for my game engine. The implementation is almost done, however I'm stuck because I need to have an access to the [texture's native pointer](
There is a method called `GetSharedHandle()` that returns an IntPtr which is what I want. But Microsoft doesn't recommand to use it and it's not working in my case (it returns IntPtr.Zero).
Having access to the native pointer is mandatory for a VR implementation using a compositor (Oculus Home, SteamVR and soon OSVR). In fact you have to create two `RenderTarget2D` and pass their `IntPtr` to the VR SDK (the Submit method in my sources).
Without that, you can only have a non direct mode rendering and have to manage the screen size, placement, etc. (this is what Oculus did when the DK1 was released).
I'm working on the three implementations (Oculus, OpenVR and OSVR).
Thanks.

Issue.Title: Problem with Graphics.PreferMultiSampling
Issue.Description:
Hi guys,
I've noticed that by default if `Graphics.PreferMultiSampling` is set to `true` you're using `32` constant value: ``
So it was a complete mystique to me and required debugging (with using MonoGame source compiled in debug mode) to determine what's going on. Of course I was able to fix this by subscribing to PreparingDeviceSettings and providing proper value to `GraphicsDeviceInformation.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleCount`. But that's not something I wish for other developers to repeat...
I would prefer to have a proper exception thrown instead of using default `32` value which in most cases will lead to these cryptic exceptions. I know it's not that easy because of current architecture, but we definitely need an improvement in that area. Even using default value `1` for `MaxMultiSampleCount` will be a better option for now. This way no exception is thrown but developer could quite easily see that multisampling is not working and first thought in that case (at least for me) is that multisample count is set to 1.
Regards!

Issue.Title: SharpDX 3.x.x update
Issue.Description:
**UPD. The information below is wrong - the performance boost was not from SharpDX improvement but from switching MonoGame to RELEASE build from DEBUG.**
I've updated SharpDX to 3.1.0 and got about 300-400% better framerate in our game. Sweet! Perhaps the improvement is so dramatic because there are a lot of drawcalls (it's too early to optimize this in our game yet).
I was needed to fix a few places in master branch of MonoGame for proper compatibility with it, also SharpDX.Mathematics.dll should be references now as it was separated from the SharpDL.dll.
There are a few drawbacks: starting from 3.0.0 SharpDX requires .NET 4.5. And a problem with MGFX - it seems when SharpDX 3.1.0 is used it tries to compile with D3DCompiler_47.dll which is available (and works) only at Windows 8.1/10 SDK, so Windows 7 is not supported. Perhaps we need to ask at SharpDX repository about this requirement as I didn't found anything related to this.
Regards!

Issue.Title: Reapplying GraphicsDeviceManager.ApplyChanges() while .IsFullScreen = true may cancel Fullscreen
Get Color by name
Issue.Description:
It would be nice if we can get color by its name (string).
A good example would be scripting. You get the color from a file as a string and you have to convert it to Color. Right now the only way to achieve this is to use Reflection which is both slow and error-prone (you risk getting a non-color property for instance, so you have to check) or make a library class (basically a dictionary) and enter all of them on your own. The second solution is fine if you want to support only a handful of colors, but it will become a real chore to input if you want to have all 140 of them.
I have a few ideas of how to implement this: 1. Use static Dictionary<string, Color> to store the colors. The static constructor will set the colors in the dictionary and the color properties will become just getters that will get the color from the dictionary. This way getting the color will be somewhat slower than it is now since it a lookup in the dictionary have to be made.
Example: ``
3. Use reflection to find the color. This way the only change made would be to write the methods, but there would be a big performance penalty because of the reflection. Personally, I don't like this solution at all, although probably it's the easiest to implement.
If the admins give it a go, I can implement one of the options (preferably the second) and make a pull request.

PullRequest.Description:

I extended the material support in `OpenAssetImporter` to export all the material features exposed by AssImp. This breaks anyone that uses `OpenAssetImporter` directly... but hopefully for the better.

Issue.Title: Specialize SpriteBatch Draw Methods
Issue.Description:
While @nkast has done some great work with his low level optimizations there is still more to be done.
For example all of these functions in `SpriteBatch`: ``
All redirect to the same `DrawInternal` method which does a common set of optimizations. We do this mainly to make the code easier to read and maintain as well as to void bugs. This however comes at the expensive of performance.
Take `void Draw(Texture2D texture, Vector2 position, Color color)` for example. This draw doesn't need rotation, doesn't need flipping of sprites, doesn't need UV calculations. If this function created its own `SpriteBatchItem` internally it could do so much more efficiently than `DrawInternal` does now.
Same goes for the other specializations of `Draw` and `DrawFont` in `SpriteBatch`. This matters when games are drawing 1000s for sprites per frame.
While this does mean a lot more duplicate code... it also means much more performance. We can deal with the issue of duplicate code via more unit tests. Performance here is more important.

Issue.Title: Certain Draw overload misplaces Rectangles and ignores scale
Issue.Description:
When using the overload `Draw(Texture2D texture, Vector2? position = null, Rectangle? destinationRectangle = null, Rectangle? sourceRectangle = null, Vector2? origin = null, float rotation = 0.0f, Vector2? scale = null, Color? color = null, SpriteEffects effects = SpriteEffects.None, float layerDepth = 0.0f)`
the scale is ignored, but only if you give a destinationRectangle (not ignored when using the Vector2 position) I get that you are supposed to supply either Vector2 + scale OR the Rectangle, but the whole overload is really misleading imo.
Edit: just found another bug with the same overload: This line works as expected: (not the buggy overload) `_spriteBatch.Draw(testTex, rect, Color.White);` while this one draws the rectangle on a completely different place: (buggy overload, should do nearly the same) `_spriteBatch.Draw(testTex, destinationRectangle: rect, color: Color.White, origin: new Vector2(rect.Width / 2f, rect.Height / 2f));`

Issue.Title: Can't create a Continuous Integration environment due to installer issues.
Issue.Description: There is no simple way, at least not one that I am aware of, to create a CI build for a UWP MonoGame project, for example.The content pipeline requires a dependency to:`<Import Project="$(MSBuildExtensionsPath)\MonoGame\v3.0\MonoGame.Content.Builder.targets" />`which is fine on a developer machine, but the main issue is that MonoGame Installer( requires administrative credentials, and that's not allowed on a build machine that you don't have admin credentials, like VSTS's Hosted Build (There should be a way to easily install all MonoGame Content Pipeline dependencies locally, or something else.It's really bad to not be able to use this kind of setup.I already apologize if there is a way that I'm not aware of, but I tried several ways to do this and got into a dead end.Maybe we can have a "portable" ContentPipeline, maybe like a zipfile with all dependencies to MGCB.exe distributed as easily as we have the MonoGameSetup.exe, on a static URL at monogame.net website.Any ideas on how to provide such a setup would be appreciated.

Issue.Title: Disposed assets loaded through a ContentManager can never be reloaded
Issue.Description: When any resource (for example a `Texture2D` or `Effect`) is loaded through a `ContentManager` instance, is then `Dispose()`d explicitly at a later time, there is no way to load this resource through the same `ContentManager` instance again.Example code:``The texture resource _"test"_ in this example can never be loaded through the same `ContentManager` again because it has been disposed and the `ContentManager` keeps a record of all resources loaded which makes it return the same disposed resource instance.I have tested this, and it works the same way with XNA, but I am wondering if this is intended behavior with disposed resources, because besides creating a new `ContentManager` instance, I don't see a way of loading a disposed resource at a later time.And to do this, I need to keep a record of disposed resources per `ContentManager` myself to predict when I need a new `ContentManager` just to load a disposed resource.My opinion on this is that when I call `Load<T>`, I do NOT expect it to return an already disposed resource, even if I disposed this resource earlier, as there is no way to remove this disposed resource instance from the internal `ContentManager` record.

Issue.Title: Content Statistics
Issue.Description: It would be very useful for the `MGCB` tool to gather content statistics. The statistics would be generated when content building occurs and would be persisted to an XML file.Example of statistics we could gather would be:- Number of models in the project.- MBs of compressed `SoundEffect` s.- Percentage of uncompressed vs compressed `Texture2D`s.- The disk space required for all content.- The approximate memory usage in game of all content.- The amount of textures in a particular folder.These statistics then could be parsed and presented in the Pipeline tool UI in some useful manner.Ideally most of the information could be gathered from the builder without the help of individual processors. Types of content, what folders they exist in, number of files, disk space required, etc can be all gathered from the outside. Things like if the content is compressed or not or the runtime memory usage would require either some cooperation from the processor to work efficiently. We could easily add additional methods to the `ContentProcessorContext` or the base `ContentItem` to help record the necessary information.This feature would make diagnosing content size issues easier and more accurate than the guessing and runtime measurements we have to do now.

Issue.Title: [WinDX] Opening Steam overlay results in "stuck" keys
Issue.Description: I'm currently working on Steam integration with my game and I came across an issue when opening the Steam overlay. The Shift and Tab keys (which you press to open the overlay) end up getting "stuck" in the game. I'm assuming this is because the Steam overlay intercepts all the key events, so MonoGame never sees the "release" events for these keys.I'm having this problem with the WinDX build, but I imagine it also affects other desktop builds. (UPDATE: This actually seems to only affect MonoGame DirectX. Both XNA and MonoGame SDL2 work correctly.)My current workaround to this issue is to clear MonoGame's internal key buffer (i.e. `Keyboard._keys`) whenever the Steam overlay is opened or closed. However given this is not publicly exposed, the only way to do this is by changing MonoGame to expose it or by using reflection. I am not sure if this is the best way of dealing with this, but it seems to work well.Has anyone else experienced this particular problem? And if so, how did you solve it?And if my workaround seems reasonable, would it be acceptable to add this to the MonoGame API (e.g. a `Keyboard.Flush` method which clears the buffer)? If so, I'm more than happy to submit a PR.

Issue.Title: SetData/GetData<T>
Issue.Description: When starting to fix #1455 I thought it might be a good idea to do parameter validation for GetData and SetData in a seperate method so we do the same checks in both, don't have duplicate code here and have a better overview of it. Maybe even abstract some of the checks up to Texture itself since this code can be shared for the most part and it'll make the checks consistent for all Texture types. I just realized the same methods exist for Vertex/IndexBuffers, not sure if we should share all around or just do textures. Thoughts on this?Also, there are cases the checks miss because sizeof(T) was is always expected to be equal to 4 (which is expected to be the size of the format, but that isn't always the case either) and the size of T is not explicitly checked while in XNA it is. I'm happy to fix all this once we decide on the above paragraphs.

Issue.Title: Calling convention incorrect for EffectsExtension in OpenGL (x86 WindowsGL)
Issue.Description: Hey,When trying to run a MonoGame application on the WindowsGL x86 platform, I get a PInvokeStackImbalance on an alGenFilters() call, and if I continue execution I get another one on alDeleteFilters():![image](I narrowed this down to the calling convention being incorrect for at least these two functions, but also likely all of the ones that are dynamically added via Marshal.GetDelegateForFunctionPointer. The main OpenAL functions declare their calling conventions as Cdecl, but those added via EffectsExtension() do not declare any calling convention at all.To fix this, I just specified the calling convention on the delegates at OpenAL.cs:546.``I don't have any other build configurations and I'm not sure if this is the correct way to fix it, so I haven't made a pull request. _Likely also need to do this with the Effect API above too,_ though my application doesn't seem to use it.

Issue.Title: Track DynamicSoundEffectInstances so they can be disposed
Issue.Description: For **XAudio**, when there are voices that are not yet disposed when [MasterVoice is disposed]( a crash will occur as noted in [`SoundEffect.Shutdown`]( This caused our unit tests to fail in #5042. We currently have [`SoundEffectInstancePool`]( to manage all SoundEffectInstances (and dispose of them in the Shutdown method) and [`DynamicSoundEffectInstanceManager`]( to manage **playing** DynamicSoundEffectInstances, but not ones that are not currently playing. I suggest we let the DSEIManager handle this by having it keep a WeakReference to all instances that are not playing as well.

Issue.Title: Add IEffect interface, so alternative implementations of Effect can be used
Issue.Description: I'm currently working on implementing a render batching pipeline for 3D rendering in Protogame, and I need some way of imitiating the "Effect" class without actually having the costs associated with it. The current render context in the engine has an `Effect` property with the `Effect` type on it.In particular, a lot of the code currently looks like:``which internally then calls renderContext.Effect or whatever.I'd like to be able to have a fake Effect, one that the render batcher can provide which tracks all of the state changes made to the effect and it's parameters (like setting of textures and other values) as the game's render loop runs.Once the render loop is about to finish, the render batcher would then look at all of the render requests that came through, sort them based on the most optimal way to run them (i.e. group requests where the effect and effect parameters are the same) and then push them to the GPU, reducing the number of draw calls to make. I want to basically take the game render loop, which may render a whole bunch of different things with different effects, and combine them together into very few draw calls, potentially also making use of `DrawInstancedPrimitives` to reduce it even further.However, so much of the code is coupled to the Effect API, and because this is a concrete class, it makes it hard to use the API without incurring associated costs, or without the render batching having to clone the effect and it's parameters on every request (itself an expensive operation).I can't just switch out Effect with some other common API either, because it implements no interfaces, and I want render batching to be optional; if you don't want to use render batching, you shouldn't have to, so it's important that the effect setup can actually be a real effect when needed, and not a fake effect supplied by the render batcher for the purposes of tracking changes.My proposal is to add an `IEffect` interface and potentially an `IEffectParameter` interface, where their signatures would match the current public APIs of the `Effect` and `EffectParameter` classes. This would allow me to transparently replace effect with a fake tracking version as needed.

Issue.Title: [SDL] Default controller axis values are wrong until manipulated
Issue.Description: Hello,With SDL, when one start a project without touching a `GamePad`, triggers axis have a wrong default value until any button/axis of the gamepad is touched.Steps to reproduce:1. Start application without touching the gamepad at all.2. Notice that `SDL_GameControllerGetAxis` returns 16384 for both of the triggers axis (should be 0) which translates to 0.5f `GamePadState.Triggers.Left` (which is supposed to be halfway in).3. Touch any axis / press any button of the gamepad (it doesn't have to be one of the triggers).4. Notice that `SDL_GameControllerGetAxis` now returns 0 and other valid values.Tested on Windows & MacOS with multiple controllers. Issue.Title: 2MGFX, warnings, optimizations and ConstantBuffer
Issue.Description: **Platform**: OpenGL**Version**: Latest commit and Release 3.5.1**Issue**: Destination offset is wrong, count is wrong**Reproducing**: This is a ~very~ specific case-scenario, but it can happen easily and there's no clear explanation of whats happening.If you declare a float4x4 in your code and only use it to get a float3 result, it will become a float4x3 with a warning ( "implicit truncation of vector type" ).Issue is, now we don't have enough space to store float4x4 data (64 bytes), only 48 bytes.Example of the problem:``This will build correctly though 2MGFX on OpenGL, but with a warning. When you apply the pass the data won't be able to be copied.**Solution**: 1. Change float4x4 to float4x3 on everything that you won't need a float4 result.or2. Change "implicit truncation of vector type" from a warning to an error.Though it's a simple mistake, I think this can be a block to newcomers (riemers.net tutorials wouldn't work, for example, which is pretty much how I started learning HLSL).

Issue.Title: RenderTarget2D throws SharpDXException when width and/or height is great enough
Issue.Description: After switching from the stable 3.5 release to the latest development build of Monogame, I ran into a few problems. One of them has been resolved already, another has an open issue, #4740, and the last is this.In my game, in order to avoid drawing a lot of tiles at once, which was eating up CPU, I set it up so that the tiles are drawn to a RenderTarget2D and the RenderTarget2D itself is drawn instead, and only updated as needed when tiles are added or removed. I initialized the RenderTarget2D something like this:`blocks = new RenderTarget2D(graphics.GraphicsDevice, 10000, 10000);`With 3.5, this works fine. But with the latest build, it throws a SharpDXException, with the following information (I edited out the irrelevant parts of the stack trace):> SharpDX.SharpDXException was unhandled> HResult=-2147024809> Message=HRESULT: [0x80070057], Module: [General], ApiCode: [E_INVALIDARG/Invalid Arguments], Message: The parameter is incorrect.> > Source=SharpDX> StackTrace:> at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()> at SharpDX.Direct3D11.Device.CreateTexture2D(Texture2DDescription& descRef, DataBox[] initialDataRef, Texture2D texture2DOut)> at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.CreateTexture()> at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget2D.GenerateIfRequired()> InnerException: Further experimentation showed that the exception is directly related to the size of the RenderTarget2D being initialized. Constructing it at a much smaller width and height works fine. I did some testing and found the point where the exception is thrown.This constructor works fine.`blocks = new RenderTarget2D(graphics.GraphicsDevice, 4096, 4096);`This constructor throws the exception.`blocks = new RenderTarget2D(graphics.GraphicsDevice, 4097, 4096);`4096 is a very binary number... That doesn't seem like a coincidence. Is this a bug or a correct limit to the size of a RenderTarget2D?

Issue.Title: Move away from XNA?
Issue.Description: Since Monogame calles itself the _spiritual successor to XNA_ and not _a Mono-compatible re-implementation of XNA_, I was wondering if there any plans to move away from the current API design to get Monogame ready for future requirements, improve components etc., essentially making it XNA-incompatible?Amongst the things which are annoying me since the early days of XNA (and now Monogame) for example is the `Game` class, the _two-step-initialization_ paradigm and the references to `Game` all over the place. It's just bad design. Also that many components which would be helpful to re-create an own, better main `Game` class are internal (e.g. `GamePlatform`).Take this for example:``What happens here? The `GraphicsDeviceManager` takes the current `Game` instance as a parameter which is essentially used to register itself in the game service collection of the game, only to be retrieved in a service-locating manner later from the `Game`. This makes it not only impossible to properly test the `GraphicsDeviceManager`, it also isn't really obvious that the game requires an instance of the type (otherwise it crashes). Not very nice.I know it's not you guys fault, it's just how XNA was designed. Hence I'm asking - are there any plans to drop the design alltogether in favor of modern standards, extensibility and more cleaner seperation of components?

Issue.Title: ExternalReference issue when loading fbx
Issue.Code: {[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.NamedValueDictionary`1[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ExternalReference`1[Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Graphics.TextureContent]] `
Issue.Description: To test #4875 I wanted to try the [InstancedModel Sample]( but I ran into some issues importing a .fbx model. - First there was a problem in the ContentWriter about writing a non-.xnb file. This was caused by [EffectMaterialContent.Effect]( being serialized, since it's an external reference to a non-xnb file. This was an easy fix, I solved it by adding [ContentSerializerIgnore] above it. - Second, there was an error thrown [here]( because the filename of the reference did not begin with the root directory, which was caused by [NormalizeOS]( in ExternalReference, since it changed directory separators in the ExternalReference so the strings didn't match up. Also an easy fix! I Changed that so it does a regular normalize rather than NormalizeOS (do the separators really matter as long as they're consistent? NormalizeOS is now not used anymore).- After that it built fine! However when loading the model it can't find the content reader for ExternalReference<CompiledEffectContent>. This is the hard one :p After digging through the code a bit, I think it should resolve to a regular ExternalReferenceReader, so it can load the file that's referenced (the reader for the effect itself is loaded, so that would work), but I got a bit confused when I saw the content readers include `` It seems weird to have a reader for a specific generic type like that, I thought a generic reader should read its content and delegate to the reader that can handle it. In this case I would expect a NamedValueDictionaryReader, an ExternalReferenceReader and a TextureContentReader to handle a type like this, each delegating internally to the next. So my question is if I should make the writer when asked for the runtime reader write out the full name of the type (e.g. ExternalReferenceReader`1[[sometype]]) or make [ContentTypeReaderManager.GetTypeReader]( a bit smarter to use a reader for the outer type when it encounters generics. I really wouldn't go for the first option, but I don't know if the second one is applicable in general (for all generic types). I think we could make it work though, and it would be **a lot** neater.

Issue.Title: .NET Native Content pipeline issue
Issue.Description: I've been having issues for months now getting the content to build in my Windows 10 Universal project using the .NET Native toolchain. I recently started a thread on the forums here:I finally tracked the issue down to this line of code: It looks like it's trying to filter out properties on the object that have been hidden using the "new" keyword in C#. Unfortunately, the trick of checking if the GetMethods for the properties are reference equal doesn't seem to work using the .NET Native toolchain. In general, this doesn’t feel like a great way to make this check. The result is that most custom content loads up with blank or null values, which causes crashes elsewhere. For my game, I just commented out that line and everything works fine. I don't do any property hiding, although I'm not sure if things would break outright even if I did. Regardless, I spent some time investigating fixes to the problem and it turns out .NET doesn't really have a great way to determine if one property is hiding another in a base class. Especially in the RT environment where reflection is limited. If possible, it seems like it might be best to not do this check at all. I’m not sure what, if anything, was actually breaking downstream before this check existed. Like I said, my project works fine without it. To find out why this code exists in the first place, I tried to track down the original commit, but haven't had much luck. I think there have been some git history rewrite shenanigans going on. You can see that in this commit ( the logic was moved from ReflectiveReader.cs to ContentExtensions.cs. But if you go through the history of ReflectiveReader.cs, you won't see that commit. Also, I can't find any trace of the property hiding check ever having been in that file. Instead you can see the changed seems to have happened between this commit ( and this commit (TLDR; The check for property hiding is sketchball and breaks .NET Native apps. .NET doesn’t provide a great way to check for this at all. Maybe you should kill it altogether. PS: The GetAllProperties() and GetAllFields() functions are misnamed. They both get very restrictive sets of properties/fields.

Issue.Title: XB1 UWP doesn't like how our static VBs and IBs are created
Issue.Description: For some reason on XB1 via UWP both `VertexBuffer` and `IndexBuffer` fail to work, but `DynamicVertexBuffer` and `DynamicIndexBuffer` work fine.What is particularly curious about this is that things work perfectly fine under UWP on Windows 10 desktops and on UWP under Raspberry Pi. Also the exact same code works on Windows 7, Vista, and Windows 8. It is just on XB1 where the non-dynamic buffers fail to work.I suspect it is either something something in buffer setup:Or it is something in the buffer `SetData` which takes a different path for dynamic vs static buffers: It could very well be that the code that has worked for 5 years now on every other DX platform has been wrong and the drivers and/or the DX runtime has been letting us get away with it.

Issue.Title: HLSL buffers incorrectly calculated?
Issue.Description: I have a shader that causes an ArgumentException, "Offset and length were out of bounds for the array or count is greater than the number of elements from index to the end of the source collection."The stack trace is as follows: at System.Buffer.BlockCopy(Array src, Int32 srcOffset, Array dst, Int32 dstOffset, Int32 count) at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ConstantBuffer.SetData(Int32 offset, Int32 rows, Int32 columns, Object data) at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ConstantBuffer.SetParameter(Int32 offset, EffectParameter param) at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ConstantBuffer.Update(EffectParameterCollection parameters) at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectPass.Apply()After some really low-level probing, I was able to determine that the effect's ConstantBuffer(s) seems to have been incorrectly allocated. My vertex shader has four float4x4 parameters, and as such, the offsets are correctly set as 0, 64, 128, 192. However, the ConstantBuffer's buffer is only 240 bytes, rather than the necessary 256. It looks as though it's reading that sizeInBytes figure from the compiled shader effect code, so does that mean the HLSL compiler is doing something wrong? Or is there something else that I'm overlooking?

Issue.Title: Mouse event handler works inconsistently on Xamarin.Mac but is fine on MonoMac
Issue.Description: I've tried doing mouse drag event handling in both MonoGame base and MonoGame.Extended and for some reason Xamarin.Mac projects do not work as expected while MonoMac projects work fine. I can capture drag events with the middle mouse button but the right and left mouse buttons do not drag. I tried this with some XNA drag and drop code I ported, and then further tested with a brand new project using the the MonoGame.Extended InputListener Demo code. This seems like a bug where the mouse movement events aren't firing for some reason while the button is in a pressed state.

Issue.Title: RasterizerState.DepthBias not working as expected
Issue.Description: The DepthBias in MonoGame is not working the same way as in XNA.I'm not 100% sure, but it looks like XNA is applying the DepthBias value set in RasterizerState in a way that matches the depth buffer format.In XNA I have used a value of -0.0004f (this is quite much) to offset a transparent area border above the landscape.This didn't work at all in MonoGame and after some investigation I found out that MonoGame just passes the value to DirectX without modification and DirectX applies it as a factor to a very small number that is calculated based on the depth buffer format.My theory now is that XNA does some math with the DepthBias value to make it easier for the developer to deal with it.In my case (24bit depth buffer) the following formula gives exactly the same visual result as -0.0004f in XNA:`state.DepthBias = (float)(-0.0004f / (1 / Math.Pow(2, 24)))`

Issue.Title: Add Color(uint) and Color(byte,byte,byte,byte) Constructors
Issue.Description: When you have to initialize a bunch of colors the current setters and constructors are inefficient. They all do internal math to scale or clamp values to back to a byte then pack them. Often this math isn't needed but is there just in case someone passes an out of range value.I suggest extending the API to support two additional constructors directly taking a packed value and channel bytes:``These would be the most efficient constructors one could use.We should also document the packed format in the reference docs on the new ctor and the packed value getter/setter.

Issue.Title: No MonoDevelop project templates install on the Linux version
Issue.Description: Unlike Visual Studio on Windows and Xamarin on Mac, if you install the Linux version (at least by using the Ubuntu install instructions) no project templates install into MonoDevelop so you're stuck using another operating system to create an empty project and then opening that project in Linux. You should just be able to select a MonoGame template when you create a new MonoDevelop project.This seems like an easy enough fix so I'm happy to try to tackle it myself if nobody else is working on it.

Issue.Title: Texture2D.FromStream Test
Issue.Description: This is something I noticed in XNA behavior porting a game to PS4.If you have a texture that is filled with the color: `R:255 G:128 B:64 A:0`. When you load this texture via `Texture2D.FromStream` the resulting texture has the color: `R:0 G:0 B:0 A:0`.If you have a texture that is filled with the color: `R:255 G:128 B:64 A:1`... `Texture2D.FromStream` returns a texture with the color: `R:255 G:128 B:64 A:1`.So although the XNA docs for `Texture2D.FromStream` explicitly state that it returns non-premultiplied colors... it does however clear the color channels if the alpha channel is 0.I don't know if MonoGame matches XNA in this regard or not. We need to implement a specific unit test with a special test texture to verify the results.Secondarily we should consider adding an overload that lets you disable this color channel clearing as it was unexpected. I can see how it would be useful to not have it modify the loaded color data.

Issue.Title: Generate PCL Assemblies using Piranha

Issue.Title: Add Ordering Tests For PackedVector
Issue.Description: Our tests for packed vector types only test against a zero and one types... it does not include tests with different values for each component. This means the tests do not correctly detect errors in the packing order.We should add a test for packing order to each of the PackedVectorTests types in:Use the test in the `Rgba64` test as the example as to how to form the new tests:While we are at this the coverage of the PackedVectorTest tests is pretty poor. We should expand these to include testing:- `IPackedVector.ToVector4()` across all types.- Equality methods across all types.- `HalfSingle`- `HalfVector2`- `HalfVector4`

Issue.Title: [DesktopGL] Heavy Song volume fluctuation
Issue.Description: Hello,First, I should note that I don't know if the problem comes from the `OggStreamer` / NVorbis, OpenAL, or my own code.When playing `Song` for an extended time (from 5 to 10 minutes, and it doesn't matter if it is the same song or a queue of different ones), it happens very often that the `Song` playing volume changes by itself without any call to `MediaPlayer` in the last couple minutes, and it can go from plain 0 to 1.This happens on all platforms, with OpenAL-Soft or Apple/Creative's one, and only affects `Song`, not `SoundEffect`.Our game can be very `SoundEffect` intensive, and `Song` are cross-faded by code. At first I thought that I was putting to much pressure on the OpenAL command buffer, but even adding locks to have a max of 10 AL calls per second doesn't change anything, and the problem can happen in moments when absolutely no `SoundEffect` is playing for several seconds.Any thoughts?

Issue.Title: Suggestion: using OpenAL Soft on OS X

Issue.Title: Color.LerpPrecise - what does the description tell?
Issue.Description: Hello, I've been playing around with colors and I got to `Color.LerpPrecise`. Now the description states the following:> Performs linear interpolation of Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color using Microsoft.Xna.Framework.MathHelper.LerpPrecise(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single) on MathHelper. Less efficient but more precise compared to Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color.Lerp(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Color,System.Single). See remarks section of Microsoft.Xna.Framework.MathHelper.LerpPrecise(System.Single,System.Single,System.Single) on MathHelper for more info.What did you guys mean "less efficient"? I know `LerpPrecise` ensures the color gets properly calculated but how is `Lerp` more efficient than it? I tried to search the internet for this but couldn't find much...

Issue.Title: SoundEffectReader Refactor
Issue.Description: I plan to refactor how `SoundEffectReader` constructs `SoundEffect`s. Currently there is this crappy `#ifdef` in there:Looking at it closer it seems to do nothing that couldn't be done within `SoundEffect` itself.My strategy is to add an internal constructor that also passes the `format` into `SoundEffect` when it is not a PCM format. Internally this would call an platform initialization method that takes a format. This allows for platform specific audio formats to work as well as formats like PCM.

Issue.Title: Pipeline Tool Issues
Issue.Description: There are a bunch of issues I noticed when using the MonoGame Pipeline tool on Windows. Some of this might be Windows specific... some of it might apply the to GTK frontend as well.- We should include the open project name in the title bar (see VS).- It isn't obvious if a content build is active occurring.- We lost the build succeeded/failed message and build time at the end of the output log.- The control border around the filter view is different that that around the output view.- The output and filter views fights the user set scrollbar position.- Text selection in the output view doesn't work correctly.- The filter view should have buttons to allow you to filter stuff out... like not showing skipping messages.- The 'References' property value should show a `;` separated string of assembly names.- Undo/Redo should be visible on the toolbar.- Toolbar icons do not update to disabled when a build is triggered.

Issue.Title: [OpenTK] DPI scaling is ignored by MonoGame
Issue.Description: Windows (with 4K displays) and OS X (with Retina displays) are using a high DPI mode which scales everything to fit high resolutions.OpenTK has internal mechanisms to handle that automatically, but MonoGame overrides the `Viewport` size (because it assumes it to be the same as the backbuffer, which is not correct when it comes to DPI scaling) and this results in cropped or too big viewport.I know that OpenTK is being replaced, but I feel like this is still an important issue and I'm leaving this here so we can keep that in mind when SDL2 will be in use (note that SDL2 <= 2.0.2 doesn't have DPI scaling support).

Issue.Title: [OpenAL] Occasionnal OggStreamer crash
Issue.Description: I've only seen this happening on OS X, but given the nature of the problem, I'm pretty sure it can happen on any OS depending on the decoding performance.A crash can occur in `OggStreamer.FillBuffer()` on the `AL.BufferData()` call with an `Invalid Value` AL error.AL documentation about this error:> The size parameter is not valid for the format specified, the buffer is in use, or the data is a NULL pointer. I haven't managed to reproduce it in a debug environment yet, but I'm pretty certain that `size` and `format` are always correct, and that `data` can't be NULL because `CastBuffer()` would throw an exception before the `ALHelper.Check()`. Hence, it most probably mean that a buffer is still in use, though it shouldn't if `AL.SourceUnqueueBuffers()` returned it...UPDATE: got it! I'm testing it before opening a PR.FYI, it is a discrepancy of OpenAL across platforms. `AL.BufferData()` generates this error if the `size` parameter is `0` on OS X, while it does nothing on Windows. Issue.Title: Pipeline tool lists content processors twice
Issue.Description: I have a .mgcb project that references DLLs with custom content processors. When I load the project in the Pipeline tool the first time, I see one entry for each of my custom processors. When I reload the mgcb project (without closing the Pipeline tool), the custom processors are listed twice:![image](I have found the following cause: [PipelineType.cs]( collects the list of processors in [ResolveAssemblies()]( It first collects all processors of the assemblies which are currently loaded in the AppDomain. Then it collect all processors from the custom content pipeline DLLs referenced in the .mgcb.This works the first time, but when the project is reloaded, the custom content pipeline DLLs are already loaded in the AppDomain and ResolveAssemblies() will find the same processors in both loops and add them twice.In my projects this is only a bit irritating but no real problem. But could this be a problem if a user tests several .mgcb projects that use different versions of a custom content processor DLL?A quick fix would be to just ignore duplicate entries. Ideally, we want to unload custom content processor DLLs before loading the next project. However, I think it is currently not possible in .NET to unload DLLs. I think we can only unload whole AppDomains.

Issue.Title: VertexElementFormat.Short4 and .Color
Issue.Description: `VertexElementFormat.Short4` and `VertexElementFormat.Color` doesn't pass through to shader correctly. Instead, they screw up the vertex input structure entirely, causing other members of the structure also become fancy.These formats must be replaced by `Vector4` (when porting from XNA) to work correctly. Issue.Title: OpenAL and maximum playing instances
Issue.Description: Hello,It looks like the maximum of playing instances on all OpenAL platforms is set to 32 (`OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES`).However, this limit is not considered in `SoundEffect` which has its own `SoundEffect.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES` set to `int.MaxValue` (DesktopGL) or `256` (XamMac).There is yet another constant in `SoundEffectInstancePool.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES`, but this one is never used. The `SoundEffectInstancePool` size is `SoundEffect.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES`.Fix proposal:- set `SoundEffect.MAX_PLAYING_INSTANCES` to `OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES` on all OpenAL platforms and cleaning the duplicated / unused values;P.S.: unless explicitly documented, it is advised to set `OpenALSoundController.MAX_NUMBER_OF_SOURCES` to 32 (most modern hardware do 64, but for compatibility it is safer to stick to 32, and there is no way to query this limit by code).P.S. 2: `MediaPlayer` uses 1 unchecked source too, which means that the limit of 32 is wrong if the real hardware limit is 32 too.

Issue.Title: MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolume may fail despite null check (WinDX)
Issue.Code:
SharpDX.SharpDXException at SharpDX.Result.CheckError() at SharpDX.MediaFoundation.AudioStreamVolume.GetChannelCount(Int32& dwCountRef) at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolumes()
2) [On this line](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/083d88ce8385cf6a454a372e1d5bbafbe83243cb/MonoGame.Framework/Media/MediaPlayer.WMS.cs#L155) or the previous one
System.NullReferenceException at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolumes() `
Issue.Description: Hello,Despite [the null check]( it may happen that `MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolumes()` raise an exception because of the async nature of Media Foundation (Windows DirectX projects).Two different (but related to the same problem) exceptions can occur.1) [On this line](``Situation 1 happens when the `_volumeController` is not yet ready.Situation 2 happens when the `_volumeController` gets reset past the null check (i.e. a new session started but didn't went through the whole initialization yet).Both are related to the async nature of starting a new session.This problem rarely occurs, over thousands of sessions, we had 4 of these crashes reported.@MichaelDePiazzi May I have your thoughts on this one? Every async initializaiton should be fine, I'm quite puzzled.

Issue.Title: Media Foundation (Song playback on DirectX) not working on Vista
Issue.Description: Hello,It appears that `Song` playback doesn't work on Windows Vista. We have several reports of this exception:``Since we can't debug on users' machines, I don't have a more precise stack trace with the native debug messages.According to this [SharpDX discussion]( Windows Vista runs a different Media Foundation version and may require an update. However, after redirecting users to the mentioned update, nothing changes and most users report that the update won't even install.At first I thought it was related to #4176 but I can confirm it isn't.The problem seems very rare, given that Vista users are now very few. There are merely a couple referenced occurrences of that problem on the internet.My best guess would be that the current version of SharpDX targets a Media Foundation version incompatible with Windows Vista.This problem, added to #4176 and the recent difficulties to rework DirectX `Song` playback make me wonder if it would be interesting to switch to another API, at least for the Windows Desktop platform (the other Windows platforms are most probably not affected by Media Foundation dependencies).

Issue.Title: Bounty: Update audio system not to drain CPU on Android
Issue.Description: The audio system stays active on Android devices and continues to drain battery when Monogame apps are in inactive in the background. This has been documented here:and here:Monogame Issue We wanted to post a $1,000 USD bounty for the successful resolution of this issue and it's acceptance into the Monogame develop branch. It looks like there are two viable solutions, one is to compile a new openal-soft library and use the new functions to pause suspend/pause the device when necessary. Another would be a fully managed mixer. Either way, this is a big blocker for anyone pushing games to production on Android, and we hope for a final solution soon :)

Issue.Title: Thumbstick inputs being clipped when using circular deadzone
Issue.Description: I've been working on improving and fine-tuning controller input for my game recently, and I've noticed when using the circular deadzone setting that the thumbsticks feel a bit too touchy.After doing some investigation, I found that the method being used in MonoGame seems to be incorrect. Here is a graph showing what it's currently doing. The colours represent the resulting thumbstick vector length: Blue = 0 (i.e. the deadzone), Green = Normal range, Yellow = 1 (i.e. full movement)![circular_deadzone_with_circular_gate](So you can see from the big thick yellow area that the values are being clipped. This results in a halfway movement of the thumbstick being equivalent to a full movement. This is not what I'd expect. And looking at Shawn Hargreaves blog article on this subject ( the graphs he provided don't seem to show any clipping being done like this. So I'm assuming this behaviour is actually incorrect.This is my expectation of what the graph should actually look like (which is in line with Shawn Hargreaves graph):![new_method_with_circular_gate](Unless anyone has reason to believe I'm wrong about this, I'm planning to submit a PR soon which corrects this.Also on a related note - While looking into this, I came across the GamePadThumbSticks.Gate property. I can't seem to find this in XNA, so I assume it's been added to MonoGame for some reason? I'm not sure exactly why this setting is needed, but the default for it is GateType.Round (which normalises the thumbstick vector if it's length is greater than 1). So if I set it to GateType.None, then the above graph now looks like this:![circular_deadzone_with_no_gate](Red means that the vector length exceeds the expected maximum of 1. So basically GateType.Round was hiding these out of range values coming from the circular deadzone function.Does anyone know why this Gate property was added to MonoGame? It seems unnecessary as the deadzone setting could be controlling this (ie. GamePadDeadZone.IndependentAxes => GateType.Square, GamePadDeadZone.Circular => GateType.Round, GamePadDeadZone.None => GateType.None). I have a funny feeling that it might have been added to correct these out of range values, so it might be unnecessary if this was the reason.

Issue.Title: Couple issues with XAudio2 (corruption, freeze)
Issue.Description: Hey there,We are getting a few reports related to sfx which may be dependent to a few sound chip manufacturers.Here are the issues, which may be unrelated, but we highly suspect that they are:1. **Sound corruption**: after playing for an extended time (~1 hour), `SoundEffect` / `SoundEffectInstance` get corrupted. All sounds start to crackle a lot. `MediaPlayer` / `Song` are not affected (which seems normal since `MediaPlayer` uses MediaFoundation and not XAudio2).2. **Freezes / stalls**: when sounds start to crackle, it is almost certain that playing a non pooled `SoundEffectInstance` (i.e. through `SoundEffect.CreateInstance()`) will totally stall the game for several seconds. `SoundEffect.Play()` (i.e. pooled instances) doesn't stall the game.I'm totally puzzled about these issues and we haven't been able to reproduce them internally which makes me think that they are related to specific sound chips and possibly driver issues.It may also be only related to looped `SoundEffectInstance`, because they tend to make the game stall more often/quickly.I also don't know why only non-pooled instances are making the game to stall. I would suspect an hardware instance limit, but since the pool doesn't have a limit on Windows platforms, the problem would have been exposed way before any non-pooled instance is played.I haven't found the time to test that against OpenAL.

Issue.Title: What is happening with Windows Phone 8.1 ?
Issue.Description: Hello,I'd like to reopen this issue with some proof that CompositionTarget.Rendering is totally broken on WP8.1 (and WP10 at some extent)- Using VS2013, crete new Visual C# -> Store Apps -> Universal Apps project. Blank App- Add function to MainPage.xaml.cs ``- Run on WP8.1 device (mine is Nokia 920 , latest firmware update).Tapping the button will print the number of times Rendering has been called- Now mash the screen with all fingers, tapping and dragging. Admitely it takes some more time than MonoGame to crash, but I can make it crash in 10-15 seconds- Now tap the button. Tap no longer works.OK, now the weird part. I was writing this message to show the evilness of CompositionTarget.Rendering, affecting touch, adding a huge delay to screen rotation, increasing global warming and in WP10 I think it's the culprit that sometimes randomly the touch locations are 'portrait' when should be 'landscape'. When I thought... this is weird, I can't see why subscribing to CompositionTarget can affect this.So, at the previous message I removed everything related to CompositionTarget, and incremented the counter each time the button was pushed. Guess what? WP8.1 still stops receiving touches.So, creating a simple XAML app, adding a button, and mashing, makes the button (and all touch) stop working in my Nokia 920.So, my question is... is it just an issue with my Nokia 920 or is somebody else able to reproduce this problem? Issue.Title: Windows DirectX VideoPlayer leaks large amounts of memory
Issue.Description: Each WMV video played would leak about 75MB of memory, rapidly increasing the amount used by the software, with disposing the videos doing nothing, even after PlatformDispose was uncommented in Video.cs.I spent a while looking into it and came to the conclusion that the cleanup process wasn't being handled correctly; MediaFoundation documentation at describes an asynchronous process of closing the session that needs to be done before the media source, then session is disposed. I couldn't find any documentation for disposing media sources without closing the session they had been used with.I came up with a first draft for a set of changes to fix this, using #4090's work on MediaPlayer as a starting point, which move the MediaSession into the Video class and have a MediaSession per video, which is closed, followed by disposal of the rest of the resources, when the video is disposed. They also dispose events received by our callback class, since not doing so causes the leak to persist, which is something that likely wants to be incorporated in any fixes to MediaPlayer's disposing of resources, too. The changes are at but this isn't suitable to merge because of some remaining issues I encountered while working on it:- The TaskScheduler-based dispatching to the UI thread used in #4090 didn't seem to be working right for me, it was running things on the thread pool, so I had to incorporate the same approach to passing tasks off to the UI thread used on Android. I suspect this could have been caused in some fashion by the particular product I was testing with, though.- Because it needs to invoke to the UI thread several times to raise events before the video enters the playing state after a call to PlatformPlay, the loop waiting for the session to enter the playing state in Play always fails. I'm not sure the best way to deal with this, but this might not be a problem if the above is fixed since it sleeps in Play and .NET pumps the message queue while sleeping/blocked on a lock by default.(In our own fork I worked around this by adding a PlayAsync method to VideoPlayer.cs, which dropped the loop-and-sleep-until-state-changed behaviour entirely, since it was desirable to make things smoother anyway by letting the rest of the program continue while the video setup happened, but this didn't fix the XNA compatible API and I've not included it in the linked branch.)

Issue.Title: MediaPlayer.Volume adjustement only works on 1st played Song

If I force the recreation of a new `MediaSession` at each play, it works. So it looks like there is a problem with retrieving the correct `AudioStreamVolume` for the given song stream. Most probably related to the fact that topology updates are async (and therefore still bound to the previous stream somehow when trying to retriever the stream volume controller).Most XAudio2 media session impletations seem to re-create a session at every play because media session updates are async. So if you guys are OK with that, I can submit a PR that Shutdown media sessions upon stop and start a fresh one upon start.It is also because of those async initialisations that getting the audio stream volume controller may fail (and needs to wait). I can clean that up and init it once the topology is correctly set (you can know that with the MediaEvent callback).Let me know if that sound coherent.
