Issue.Title: Draw timing issue when Nvidia 3D Vision is activated - workaround included
Issue.Description: ## IntroductionFirst of all I want to point out that this issue may be more important than you may think at first because it may happen in every monogame, even if it's pure 2D. Even worse, a usual player that owns 3D Vision may not even have the idea that the graphic glitches he is seeing may be related to 3D Vision, he forgot to deactivate.## SymptomsSo now for the issue itself. After experiencing random graphic glitches I wrote a sample code as simple as possible (see below). In order to run it you will need1. a new plain Windows Desktop monogame project2. a resource file named "pixel.xnb" which is a 2D-Texture that simply contains a single black pixel.What it does is to draw a horizontal black line with a height of 5 pixels on a white background and move it vertical in steps of 5 pixels every frame. Works perfectly with 3D Vision deactivated but if 3D Vision kicks in the following happens:![timingglitch](It turned out that it was impossible to get a regular screenshot from the glitch, so I needed to take a photograph of my screen. So please ignore the unsharp grey stripes - they are a side-effect of taking a photograph of the screen and not really there. What is the real glitch are the 3 thin horizontal lines, there only should be one, which is the lowest of them.If you could see the movement: The glitch lines appear to be flickering (I think about 20 times/second, see my theory below). But taking a video of the glitch is even more impossible (120 Hz video camera, anyone? :D ). Then the glitch lines change their position at random points of time.Looking through my 3D glasses it appeared that the glitch lines are only in the half-picture intended for the right eye, the left eye looks normal.## Theory After some research about the internal workings of DirectX graphics and how Monogame uses it I came up with the following theory how this happens:1. Monogame creates a swapchain in the video memory which consists of a screen buffer and 2 back buffers2. since 3D Vision needs 2 half-pictures it creates secondary buffers for the right eye. It doesnt tell the application anything about that (wouldn't be possible with older 3D games that are automatically converted into stereo 3D)3. When a Frame should be drawn, Monogame sends draw instructions to the graphics card and waits until they are executed, then presents the next buffer in the swapchain.4. Monogame (or SharpDX?) uses some unusual way to determine when the draw operations are finished. At least I assume it must be unusual since I never noticed the same problem in other 3D games. The call returns when the first buffer has been drawn, the secondary buffer has not yet been drawn.5. Under normal circumstances the next Frame is drawn now. If that happens the preceding draw operations are cancelled. The secondary buffer remains unchanged.6. only at random times (for example when the operating system gives cpu time to another thread or process) the graphics card is given enough time to execute the drawing operations for the seondary buffer. Then the secondary buffer is changed.7. The screen is presented with the contents of the primary and secondary buffers. Since the secondary buffer contains an old version of the drawing from some random point of time in the past, a flickering ghost will appear. Since there are 3 secondary buffers it flickers at a rate of 120 Hz / 2 (half pictures/second) / 3 (buffers/half-picture) = 20 Hz There are up to 3 ghosts, because we have 3 secondary buffers.## WorkaroundTo test my theory I just gave the graphics card more time to finish by adding a Thread.Sleep() to the draw cycle. To test remove the slashes from the line `Thread.Sleep( (int)gameTime.ElapsedGameTime.TotalMilliseconds/8);` in my code sample. I found the appropriate amount of time with trial and error, it may be system dependent.On my system this removes all the graphic glitches.## Suggestions for SolutionThe second best solution would be to deactivate 3D Vision in Monogame completely. There is an API (nvapi.dll) that allows game developers to control 3D vision, so Monogame would need to check wether it is present and make the appropriate calls.The best solution would be of course to fix the source of the problem since this would allow to write 3D-vision compatible games with Monogame.## Code``

PullRequest.Title: Android : Housekeeping
PullRequest.Description: - Fixed support for creating textures with a surface format of type SurfaceFormat.Bgra4444. An internal format of type Rgba4 was specified, which is not supported in GL.ES20.- Changed existing graphics capabilities checks when reading in a 2d texture to additionally apply to both iOS and Android platforms. Issue.Title: Possible OpenGL depth range / clipping bug
Issue.Description: It's very possible that I'm missing something obvious.But it seems to me that MonoGame does not account for the difference in NDC space between Direct3D and OpenGL.In Direct3D, the Z-coordinate in NDC ranges from 0 to 1, while in OpenGL it ranges from -1 to 1. So in Direct3D, anything in NDC space with `z < 0` will be clipped, while in OpenGL anything in NDC space with `z < -1` will be clipped.The `Matrix.CreateOrthographic*` and `Matrix.CreatePerspective` methods use Direct3D conventions, so the NDC depth range created by these methods is from 0 to 1.As far as I can see, that means that MonoGame's OpenGL renderer only ever uses half of the available depth range. Worse, near plane clipping doesn't work properly, because objects that _should_ be behind the near clip plane, and therefore clipped, in fact aren't, because the near clip plane ends up (potentially) behind the camera. (That's how I noticed this bug - something that should have been clipped wasn't being clipped.)The only mention I can find of this issue is over on FNA, here: flibitijibibo/FNA#282. @flibitijibibo mentioned a possible solution: `glClipControl`, and implemented it for FNA [here]( but it's only available in recent versions of OpenGL. You can also modify the `Matrix` methods that create projection matrices, but obviously that's not a general solution. @flibitijibibo has also added a note to the FNA docs about the issue, [here](But I feel like I must be missing something, because surely this would have been noticed before now?_(Note: MonoGame uses `posFixup` to account for the difference between Direct3D and OpenGL in the 0 location for the screen-space Y-coordinate. That's related to this, but it doesn't solve the NDC Z-coordinate problem.)_

Issue.Title: Consider implementing / exposing texture arrays
Issue.Description: In Direct3D, there's an `ArraySize` property for textures, which I think would be really useful to expose:``OpenGL has [array textures]( which look like the same thing (although not supported by OpenGL ES 2.0).I think this could be a backwards-compatible change: if you want to `SetData` on one of these, you'd use the `level` parameter. You'd calculate the value for the `level` parameter using something similar to Direct3D's [D3D11CalcSubresource]( which we'd need to expose as a new API.If this looks like something that would be of interest, then I'd be happy to work on a PR. I just wanted to first see if it matches MG's goals.(My use-case: for cascaded shadow maps, it's nice to use a Texture2D array. The alternative is to use a single texture containing all the shadow maps, with offsets to sample from the correct cascade. It's certainly do-able without texture arrays, but more elegant with them.)

Issue.Title: iOS freeze & crash when attempting to resume following incoming call
Issue.Description: When returning to a monogame game having received a call, the game screen displays, but updates do not resume. After about 10 seconds, the game crashes and returns to the home screen.This occurs in the latest stable monogame build and development versions from just before this point until now.Steps to reproduce:1) Create a new iOS Universal app in Xamarin studio2) Set up a standard "cornflower blue" game1 boilerplate class and update the AppDelegate and Main.cs files to run this.3) Modify the game1 update and draw calls so that the ongoing updates can be seen (I put in a simple timer to display gameTime.TotalGameTime on the draw call)4) Run the app (I was using an iPhone 5c running iOS 8.1)5) Call the phone running the app6) When the phone running the app switches to display the incoming call, hang up7) The phone running the app will now return to the app, but the display will no longer update. After about 10 seconds, the app will crash.

In the actual code there is a separate SpriteBatch set to use the multi blend shader to draw both textures.Note: The rocks around the player/placeholder changed since I restarted/rebuilt the game each time and therefore the map was randomly rebuilt each time.Since I'm quite confused now whether it's my bad or not I couldn't help myself besides posting this as an issue here. I am working on a Linux platform and even tried the WinGL assembly, but I still got this (unwanted) result.The c# code where this issue occurs looks like this (completly from the shading system mentioned above):``Sorry, if this is my issue and not yours, but I don't quite understand shaders yet and I didn't make any changes except the assembly-version I use (both are marked as 3.1.2.0 though).Oh, while writing this I remembered: The "old" assembly was not the official 3.2 one. It was the one from the "MonoDevelop Alpha Add-In Package" (.mpack) that @cra0zy (or however his name is spelled, sorry) posted. I'm unsure which version this actually is since they are all marked as 3.1.2.0...

Issue.Title: [Solution]Monogame PSM not rendering texture
Issue.Description: I decided to give a try to the PSM part and when I tryed to draw simple texture I ended up with null pointer exception it turns out that inside SpriteBatcher method DrawVertexArray I had to add the following code in order to work : if(effect == null) { var vertexCount = end - start; _device._graphics.DrawArrays(DrawMode.Triangles, start / 2 \* 3, vertexCount / 2 \* 3);} else { var passes = effect.CurrentTechnique.Passes; foreach (var pass in passes) { pass.Apply(); _device._graphics.DrawArrays(DrawMode.Triangles, start / 2 \* 3, vertexCount / 2 \* 3); }}I hope that can help someone :)

Issue.Title: Mouse position bug under High DPI on Windows
Issue.Description: My "FPS camera" code, that constantly resets the mouse position to the centre of the window, worked in XNA but doesn't (quite) work in MonoGame. It _sometimes_ works, but other times, if you leave the mouse stationary, it still thinks the mouse is moving by 1 pixel in the X or Y direction.I've tracked the problem down to DPI scaling. If I set my DPI scaling to 100%, there's no problem. But with 150% scaling, there seems to be a problem with mouse position getting rounded. I haven't looked into it yet, but I guess that somewhere between setting the mouse position and retrieving it, there's a float getting rounded to an int, or something, which means MonoGame constantly thinks that the mouse has moved by a little bit, even if it hasn't.I'll work on a pull request for this, but I wanted to raise this issue first in case anyone else has experienced this issue. Do any MonoGame developers have DPI scaling enabled on their monitors?

Issue.Title: Textures should always be assigned to device, even if they are null
Issue.Description: I'm not sure if I'm right about this, which is why I'm creating an issue, not a pull request. If it is indeed a bug, then I can create a pull request.It seems to me that this line is wrong:I think we should remove the null check, and always set the texture, even if it is null.For example, if the previously bound texture is a TextureCube (well, Texture2D array, in Direct3D 11 terminology), and the new texture is a Texture2D, but it just happens to be null, then it's still necessary to set that texture slot to null, otherwise Direct3D will complain that the currently bound texture has the wrong dimension for the current shader. (I have this exact situation, which is how I found this.)
